145346028.review:
Eternal Senia, this is the first part of two games. Both games are amazing. A deeply story driven game, about two sisters that are willing to do anything for the other. As it goes along, Senia steadily goes from being passive to more determined. Her determination connecting to her desire to save her sister. From end to end, this game will tug at the heart. If anything, expect multiple endings. There are three, the canon one is the third, as it leads into the second game.

Now as for the mechanics, they are pretty simple but effective. There is a steady progression, with crafting and all. As for the battle system itself, it steadily unfolds with plot reasons being how Senia learns her skills. Basically, everything has something to do with the story. It isn't a long game, and that is fine. The devs set out for what they wanted to do, and they nailed every part.

For those wondering on the second game. I highly recommend it. Don't worry that it is a gacha, since they give away a lot of free gems every day. So, it is pretty easy to progress. And the storyline is amazing, and complete.

136233971.review:
So I was randomly looking up some obscure RPG lists and someone mentioned this on Reddit, decided to look it up and then give it a go because it looked interesting (and it was free), and holy sh*t was I surprised. Upon first experiencing that bump combat it felt like I was playing Ys 1 all over again, and I knew I was in for a treat from there on out! The combat is very well done and the bosses are really creative, in both gameplay and design (seriously, they look great)! ...and the bosses are hard as nails on hard mode.

The OST is also super catchy and contains some really chill songs. Could definitely see myself listening to the OST outside of the game. Annnnnnnnd the story is super compelling! Ending 2 is honestly one of the darkest endings to a game I've seen from memory, damn. 

All in all, a SUPER well made game! It's not everyday you see a free Steam game live up to this kinda quality. Solid 8/10 from me. Only complaint really is the wonky translation at times, but my tolerance for that kinda thing is pretty decent, so it doesn't bother me too much. 

MIGHT play the mobile sequel at some point, but not too sure... went to look up gameplay after finishing this and boooooy does it look rough in comparison. Criminal it wasn't just in the same gameplay style as this on PC again, but oh well. 

But seriously, go play this, it's awesome. One of the better action RPGs I've played in a good while now.

133842107.review:
It’s hard not to recommend a free game, especially if its gameplay turns out to be quite enjoyable. In the beginning you just run into enemies to deal damage to them (and take some damage in return) but by the end you have a handful of abilities you need to use to take enemies out quickly enough while dodging AoE attacks. The bosses are very well designed to have a certain rhythm to them. Other than that there is a simple process of collecting materials to upgrade weapons and armour. It’s complex enough that it feels fulfilling while not being too much of a chore. 

The plot is… ok. You’re going through levels of a tower (dungeon) to find your sister. A surprisingly decent background is revealed through flashbacks, but it’s nothing too deep. The worst part of the game, in my opinion, is the dialog. I think the designer is Taiwanese so English might not be his first language. But beyond that, the dialog just seems like a first draft. Lots of “Eh?!”, “…”, and most annoying, simply “!”

It’s about 4 or 5 hours to finish, depending on how much you grind. The last two boss battles took me a few attempts. They were surprisingly challenging, but satisfying to beat because it was my own skill not my character’s stats that was needed for victory. 

If you’re in the mood for an old-school RPG feeling that is simple enough to pick up for a few hours and still feel like you’re making good progression and getting powerful, I  would recommend this.

121343505.review:
RPGMaker XP was a neat little tool that allowed anyone to make a game regardless of skill, and while we had several updated versions of it throughout the years, there was a time where the popularity and creativity of games being made in XP exploded. Eternal Senia is one of those "well made" games from that era, instead of just using the stock turn based system, the developer coded in his unique battle system that is obviously inspired by action rpg legends like "Ys 1 and 2". 

The game is short, you can easily beat it in 2 hours if you rush and just want to get the bad ending, but if you want to 100% and unlock the true/alt ending.. you can easily take up to 5 hours. 

For a free RPGMaker XP game, its not bad... weirdly enough, the developer would actually develop a sequel years later which skyrocketed the production values....

But sadly... it was a mobile gacha :(

118669497.review:
Eternal Senia is a fantastic game if you want something extremely simple but interesting. For someone like me, who reached peak burnout with life as a whole, Eternal Senia is the sort of game I could actually still play despite that. The story is good, the characters are fun. The graphics are as simple as the gameplay, and the only gripe I have with the latter is that your movement can get stuck sometimes--NOT ideal when you're trying to get away from something.

Two words of caution:

1) You can't go back once you've ascended to another level, so many sure you synthesise every sword and armour you can and grab all the skill-level drops you feel you will want on the level you're on. At the end of the game, you can get something good for having synthesised everything to that point to legendary, but if you forgot something, it's either give it up or restart from the beginning.

2) The ending is not really an ending, so much as it is a "to be continued", no matter which ending you go for. They want you to grab the sequel, which in of itself is fine, except the sequel is an entirely different game. It's not a simple JRPG, it's a button-mash clicker mobile game that forces you to grind quite a lot, as all mobile games do. If that's cool with you, dive right in. If you're like me, and exhausted straight to Hell with grind-fests, then maybe don't.

While there is a bit of a translation error here and there, it's nothing major.
Visuals and sound design is wonderful, especially for a free game.
Overall it's not difficult to 100% and only takes a couple of hours while being a great story, so definitely give this one a go.
Though that being said it's a bit tragic that the sequel went the route of a clicker mobile game when this one has so many good ideas that would have made for a fantastic second game if fleshed out more.

Hello there!                                                                                                                         Rate: 06\10

So you're looking at reviews trying to see if this game is something you may enjoy? well you have came to the right place. Let me have a moment of your time and you can read my experience about how i felt as i played through this game and then you can compare with other players to gather all the information you need to make your choice.

I will separate my experience into categories to give you the best look at what playing the game may look like.

(NO SPOILERS)

First impressions - My original feelings about the game were quite all over the place, being that my only experience with a game like this is Dragon Quest nine on the old Nintendo. That being said i thought i would try it out and see how i would feel as i have not played a game like this in some time.

Story - The story is quite average when compared with most other games on the market, you learn more of what led you to where you are the more you play through the game rather than it being a present story which i did find underwhelming if i am honest. I found that i did not have much care for the story until the ending where the game did invoke some emotion in me and that i am pleased with but other than that i found the story to be tiring.

Game-play - The game play was put at a disadvantage i think as it does not have a full-screen mode in the game or at least mine did not meaning my enjoyment was not what it could have been and made the game feel less immersive. The combat felt very satisfying in some parts and the movement at a nice speed. When the game makes you fight a clearly stronger enemy than the grunts you did to get to that point, it seemed it happened too often which seemed quite repetitive and left the battle feeling less intense but i do commend them for having a difficulty changer before you do start battling and the save feature is placed in good locations and is easy to use. I will mention what i previously stated in the story is that you already know your mission from the start meaning everything in-between felt like a long journey, personally that is not to my taste but i understand other players do enjoy that way of playing.

Characters- The main characters i do like and feel they are made well, they have their own personalities and their own priorities meaning you get to know them more as real people. You can understand the way they think and why they think those things, the same cannot be said for any other characters i am afraid, in my opinion they felt quite lifeless and empty. You do not learn much about them and understanding them is practically impossible. You may learn what they do or how they may help you but besides from that i feel the only two fleshed out characters are the protagonists.

Art design - The design of pictures and the game itself are nice and look polished, i felt the colours went along with whatever moment setting i was in. The picture design i can't say is to my liking due to the fact i am very specific when it comes down to something like that.

Controls - The movement controls are standard and easy to use just like your crafting control, interacting and cancel controls but he combat controls do feel a tad straining and i got them mixed up at points. I would often not use one or two attacks to keep it simple but this could be my lack of experience in this type of game.

Music - The music suits the game, i must admit i did not pay much mind to it but in some scenes i did and felt it was just right and pretty at times. It never felt out of place or over-bearing so i liked it and thought it added feeling to the atmosphere.

Replay aspect - The replay ability in this game is obvious, i can see someone enjoying it and doing over again. 

Free to play- It is a free game so there is no reason to try it out for yourself as your experience might very well differ from mine or any other player review you may read.

Achievements - There are no achievements in this game and i do think it would be nice to have some as you don't feel that you are rewarded other than the fact you complete the game.

Multiple ending - There are multiple endings which i am glad it has, i felt it made my experience that more exciting though it is disappointing as it is not like you do things differently from the start or take a different path. It is a different outcome at the same end. You get a little bit more of a different experience but even in that there was a level of repetitiveness of what you had to do. There are three endings but one is playing the game normally, second is being right near the end and playing about 10- 20 minutes longer in a different area to end up in the same place where you make a choice. That choice of two things is your second and third ending which is a shame but i am glad it is there even if there is not much of it.

Duration - The duration of play time it takes to complete the game and get all three endings is around four hours and thirty minutes (4 hours 30 minutes), thirty minutes of that (30 minutes)  more or less was for the other two endings.

My experience - Now i know i have said a lot and there is a lot of negative things i may have had to say but that is just me reviewing my experience and my time playing. This is how i felt and i would be lying if i said i did not enjoy it, at the end i just felt a bit short handed with the time spent. As i stated beforehand, you could play the game and feel very differently to me but the only way to do that is to try it put for yourself. If you are bored and need to kill time then i would say this game is perfect for it!

Thank you for reading about my time playing this game and in doing so i hope that i have helped you come even a little bit closer to a decision of what do to with this game. If you do choose to play then feel free to let me know how your experience went down below! i am always eager to see how others react.

108514593.review:
Eternal Senia is an RPGMaker game about how a teenager needs to mob through enemies in a tower to get her sister back.  Beat it, 100%'d everything, got all endings, and visited the bonus dungeon in 6.4 hours using a keyboard.  Difficulty is easy.  

Gameplay - This is an action rpg like the first YS games, where you bump enemies to death.  You can also cast special moves on the side.  Everything ran smoothly more or less and fighting the bosses is extra fun.  Bosses have an easy and hard mode, and easy was way too easy for me.  But the final battle was really hard in hard mode.  There's no penalty or benefits to either outside of challenge.  

Controls - The controls were a little weird but were easy to get use to in time.  I sorely wanted to use a game controller and it's not really a realistic option.  There's no way to change the controls in-game.  Another weird bit is how the game doesn't remember the screen size I wanted (every time I started it up I went into settings to redo it).

Graphics - Classy RPGMaker graphics.  AWESOME character art and scene pictures.  Also awesome boss art.  

Music - Classy RPGMaker music.  Unsure if it's all pre-set rpgmaker music or if anything unique had been composed in the bunch.  

Plot - The plot really makes Eternal Senia.  I Loved the plot.  Many others in the reviews have as well.  I love the endings, and I love Senia.  

Translation - The creator is not a native English speaker.  That said, the English translation could use some work or updates.  

Free - It's Freeeeeeeeeeee!!!  And it shouldn't be!  Give me a donate option!  Curse you, let me support you for such a good game!

Bugs - I experienced a number of weird bugs.  Some involved movement or the character sprite seizing up, and Q-ing through doorways into cutscenes crashed it so don't do that.  There were a few other really random ones that I don't remember offhand.  But none of it really got in the way of playing.  



Eternal Senia is free, fun, and fast for an rpg.  It's the least stressful arpg I've played in quite a long time.  The characters and loveable and bosses are great to fight.  If you want to get away from life for all of five or so hours and need a safe spot to chill out, this is a great game for that.  I want to replay it.  Chances are I will in the future.  I want to play the sequel.  Is there a sequel?  Please let there be a sequel.

102791093.review:
I was impressed!  As many people know, RPG Maker games can be very hit or miss.  When I first started this game, the translation through me off a bit and I was unsure if I was going to like it or not.  I'm glad I gave it a shot!

I'm not entirely sure if the music was bought or made by the developer, but the music is fantastic.  I really enjoyed the "if you touch the enemy, you instantly hit each other" mechanic.  This means there wasn't a point where the enemy was moving faster than I could keep up, and I was getting whooped because of it.  Basically, if a baddie bumped into me, we hit each other.

That being said, there are still four simple skills you can use to help yourself out, including one that is used in puzzles.  You can level these skills up with points you get along the way.  The monsters respawn, so you can grind to your heart's content.

I also enjoyed the "procedural" mini-dungeons within the areas that you could go to and grind even more, or find other items that may not be in the normal game.  

Another HUGE benefit this game had that I wish every game had was the NPCs at the end of each area.  One NPC gave you rewards for obtaining each upgrade, one for killing an amount of each monster, and the last for finding each treasure.  These NPCs made sure you didn't miss anything or leave anything behind.

I wish there had been a way to "hide" items I've already crafted, because finding where I left off was a bit of a pain.  The crafting system is basically your only way to get upgraded equipment.  It isn't too hard to use...but it felt like a chore to unequip everything I was wearing so I could go to the crafting menu and scroll past all the stuff I already made and then upgrade my current equipment and then go back and reequip it.  This may have just been a limitation of RPG Maker.

All in all, I'd love to see what this developer could produce with a team and more resources.  I suspect that they had a lot of ideas that never got used.  The homage to old school RPGs is definitely there...the forest level gave me serious "Secret of Mana" vibes.

102621595.review:

102533108.review:
An absolute beauty! I can't even begin to tell you how wonderful this game is. I just finished the game completely and saw there's a sequel coming [i] (Or already out not sure) [/i] , but I am very excited to play it when I can. Like a said before, an excellent game, and for free to, it's insane! 

[b] Now a basic review from a first time player: [/b]
Everything in Eternal Senia is wonderful, the story, characters, bosses, upgrades, and all of the endings. I'm not the best with reviews since I don't really do them, but here we go-

[b] Game Controls: [/b]
The game controls are very easy to get a hold of and you should have almost no problem with them. I will say I wish there was an option to change your controls as even I was slightly confused when first playing. But like I said very easy to get used to, so even if you have trouble you should be fine.

[b] Difficulty: [/b]
Now the difficulty wasn't actually too hard for me. I had an easy grasp on the game and got used to the attacks damages. If you're like me then you will grind out mobs and constantly upgrade, so that might have been why the game was easier on my part. If you forget to upgrade your gear then the game will most likely be a lot harder. The bosses also have an easy and hard mode, I haven't clicked either and just did the normal difficulty so I'm not sure how hard or easy it is.

[b] Story: [/b]
Now the story is very simple, but it's a nice story. The whole story is about Senia going after her sister to find her, and on her adventure Senia grows mentally while staying determined. It shows the devotion of how far will you go to protect the ones you love. If you love angst and the feels, then I recommend this even more.

[b] Graphics: [/b]
The graphics are beautiful and visually appealing. The little sprites of the characters, the visual novel feel to the game, the backgrounds, the bosses, and all attacks. Everything is nice to look at and you don't have to feel like you're being overwhelmed by colors. You can also change the brightness of the game so if the game is too bright for your nightowl eyes, then you can turn it down.

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]
Finally the soundtrack, which is amazing. I love the soundtrack in this, even if I have to listen to it for a hour or so, I don't really get bothered by it. Most of the time intense music will only activate if you're in a certain area like a boss fight or a new area. But even then there's still music playing constantly but it's not as prominent which I really like. 

Overall this game is lovely to play, and I couldn't recommend it enough. If you want a free visually appealing game to play in your free time, then play Eternal Senia because you will not regret it.

101822263.review:
[h1]Important:[/h1] This review is giving the game a [b]Neutral[/b] rating. (why do we only have a Yes/No option instead of a score system ?)

Anyways, Eternal Senia is a small RPG that could probably be considered a light novel, the main focus here is the story.

[h1]+Positives:[/h1]
+Good story with some good characters
+Good art (at least during cutscenes)
+No bugs encountered
+I guess being free should count as a positive

[h1]-Negatives:[/h1]
-Bad gameplay
-Too easy
-No worldbuilding outside of the 'dungeon' that the main character is in during the whole game
-Made with RPGMaker


[h1]+Story:[/h1]
(I will not spoil the story, but just in case I will put the finer details in spoilers)

You play as Senia, a [spoiler]orphaned[/spoiler] young girl who was raised by a young woman of faith. Senia finds herself in some sort of dungeon filled with monsters with the objective of finding her dear sister [spoiler]whom has left her to the Tower of Eternity in search of the powers held within. As Senia ventures throughout the tower she learns more and more about the terrible nature of this thing Magaleta yearns for and why she left her.[/spoiler]

In my personal opnion I think the story was good with a very bittersweet/sad ending and good characters, only citicism I have to give is that we aren't really given any info about the world outside of this dungeon.


[h1]-Gameplay:[/h1]
 Oh boy, this is going to take a while.
I'll be honest, it's absent. Unlike most RPGMaker games that are normally either turn based RPGs or completely devoid of combat and instead are filled with puzzles, Eternal Senia tries to well... kind of mimic the gameplay of the older Zelda games (top down view, enemies roam the screen and you walk up to them to then attack them and you have a dash that reflects projectiles and an AOE attack) however there is one major difference, instead of having a button for normal attack you have to directly run into an enemy and you'll deal damage to them while also recieving damage from their attack.... The whole gameplay is touch damage. Of course there are the AOE and Dash skills however these consume mana so you end up with 2 problems; either the game is too easy if you've been farming and keeping your gear up to date as enemies that you walk into deal literally 1 point of damage OR the game is impossible if you've been rushing because you [b]have[/b] to take damage in order to deal damage which ends up degenerating into you avoiding enemies until your mana refills so you can use skills to kill enemies without taking damage.
 The AI of most enemies also is rather absent due to the system I previously mentioned, since you must walk into enemies to harm them they'll simply wander around the room not really chasing you or anything except for spellcasters or enemies that have a charge attack. Enemy variety is also very lacking as it can be summed up to 4 categories; Grunts that can only walk into you to deal damage, Chargers that are the same as grunts but have a charge attack that renders them immune to damage and will guide them towards you, Shooters same as grunts but will keep shooting projectiles in front of them (not neccesarily aimed at you) and Spellcasters which have a ranged AOE attack.

While I do respect the fact that the developer tried something different, RPGMaker just isn't the right engine for this kind of game.


[h1]+Art:[/h1]
I do like the art at least the one during dialogues and cutscenes, sadly the sprites outside of the cutscenes aren't very impressive but that's a limitation of RPGMaker (it isn't exactly known for it's stunning triple A graphics)  the colors are very soothing and the characters look adorable.


[h1]+Bugs:[/h1]
Thankfully none were found while I was playing, although it is reported that sometimes exiting a room by dashing might glitch the game if there's a cutscene that triggers in the next room.


[h1]-Final Verdict:[/h1]
If I had to rate this game I'd give it a 6,5/10; good story but bad gameplay.
If you have a couple of hours to spare and want a nice little story I'd recommend playing, if you're looking for a game to have fun playing with then probably not. All in all it's free and somewhat short, nothing to really lose by playing it (we all know you are going to lose that time procrasinating anyways.)

101483763.review:
I didn't realize a game like this could end up being as deep as it was. It starts off like, really REALLY simple. Like I thought, hey, just walk into things and they die? Is this some mobile game? (yes, I know the sequel is one, unfortunately)

Eventually as enemies started having more varied things to worry about, and skills started to be tacked on, I started feeling some challenge. I was ultimately super challenged by the final boss (i did every boss on hard mode) and took like literally 1.5 hours to beat that.

In the end, it was super worth it, and the music was super great and memorable. Though I think a lot of it was copyright free? I also recognized a generic RPG Maker song in there but I didn't really mind.

I ended up collecting everything in each chapter and doing every boss on hard mode. It was a great experience.
Here's my playthrough if anyone would like to check it out :)
https://youtu.be/-wrpyKkiqIo

96512436.review:
I haven't played this game since 2016, but I'll try my best to make a review based on what I can remember.

Starting with a TL;DR, I loved everything about this game, it was a masterpiece and that should be pretty clear from the reviews, they've been overwhelming for several years already. I feel bad about the game being free, I'd throw money at it if I could just to support the developers. I loved the game so much that I was keeping up with the progress of their sequel.

I initially installed this game based on the gameplay, I was in the mood for such gameplay and I stumbled upon this game and thought, if it's free then I've got nothing to lose except time. As you can tell, I did not install it for the story, but lo and behold, I got captivated by the story, who would have thought.

The music, the goddamn music, I loved it. I can't tell you that every OST slapped, but the majority did, and I remember chilling at the title screen for who knows how long, because I just kept listening to the music, the music was so good that the negative reviews still call the music "a redeeming point of the game".

The gameplay is fun, this is the first and last time I've seen the use of abilities in this game genre, and being able to level your abilities with resources instead of EXP was also a very fun and innovative decision. Then there's the fun boss fights and sort of dungeon-like entrances, that allowed you to farm and also battle bosses outside of the story, it appealed to my MMORPG heart.

If I absolutely have to mention a negative point to this game, it would be the constant promotion of their Facebook page to claim a code, but the issue was that the Facebook page was nigh impossible to find with English characters, so I had to find the code through a fan-page, but the fan-page was run by a suicidal individual, it made me very uncomfortable, I was a kid back then mind you.

95528282.review:
A compact but powerful experience.  Each level is well designed, with complexity ramping up over time; they have just the right amount of depth and variety, and it is possible (and optimal) to "full clear" each level, providing an avenue for satisfactory optimality. The story is brief, meaning concise, and its brevity of pacing complements the levels well.  As for the narrative itself, it had a great impact on me; I cried a few times.

Reading the developer notes (post-completion), you can tell that the developer has thoroughly studied the classics and their basic principles of game design, and adapted their successful elements into his action RPG.  An outstanding work all things considered, and among my favorite RPGs.  This is the true power of a passion project!

A very slow start, the first level that's pretty much tutorial almost had me thinking this would be rather boring. No real variety, no strategy, just move forward, run yourself into monsters till they die, proceed. BUT it does get much better after that! 94558093.review: This is a very satisfying JRPG with Legend-of-Zelda-like combat (real-time attacks performed in any of the four cardinal directions) and stereotypically bad English translation. As a result of the real-time, arcade-like combat, this is one of the best indie JRPGs I've played, and the fact that it's free makes it all the more enjoyable. There's a few mechanisms that add a little hint of complexity as the game continues: inventory management, item crafting, and using up to four special attack powers. It's not complicated, but there're enough additional things to do that it spares the gameplay from being exhaustingly repetitive. There is a fair amount of repetition, still, but the game doesn't use it to drag out the gameplay and I never felt like I had to linger in an area or repeat anything to grind for more power or equipment. It's just the right length. You can play through [u]Eternal Senia[/u] casually over the course of a day, or you can try to find all the chests and upgrade all the equipment in each of three worlds/zones for an extra challenge that adds up to a few hours. My final save file shows that I played the game, from start to finish, in a bit over 9 hours, and while I felt a little conflicted over spending so much time on a free game when I have so many I've paid money to add to my library, I enjoyed every minute of it.

94469435.review:
Was recommended this game by a friend and played through the whole thing in two nights. I was expecting to enjoy it, but not nearly as much as I did - this game blew me away!

The combat was super fun, and a great approach to real time combat that avoids frantic button-mashing. Things were usually straightforward, but there was a learning curve on the bosses that provided a really fun challenge. I will note that my game ended up glitching during the "King" mini boss battles 2 dungeons through, but even with the issue, I was able to strategize to account for the glitch and play through. 

I wasn't expecting much from the story, but I feel like I underestimated the game in doing so. I was really moved by the characters and wanted to learn more about them with each cutscene. I'm a sucker for a story about family, and this hit me where it hurt. I was so moved by the dynamic between the sisters. This game made me cry!

I also want to say that I absolutely adore the maps here. I don't really like the RPG Maker VX/VX Ace art style, it looks too blocky for me. It tends to have two impacts on me: 1) looking REALLY fake, and 2) feeling like you're stuck *inside* of something, like a diorama. But this game's setting suited both of those things absolutely perfectly, and made those traits feel like a feature, not something disappointing. 

I really recommend giving this game a shot!

92316902.review:
TLDR: Play it.

Is Eternal Senia the best game ever? No. Is Eternal Senia the best RPGMaker game ever? No. Is Eternal Senia a lovely experience in which the passion of the creator clearly shines through? Absolutely yes. 
Eternal Senia is a short but very enjoyable game that I highly recommend. It's not that grindy, especially if all you want to do is "finish" the game. The game is thankfully very forward about how to get the most enjoyable experience; the creator at one point tells you what to do, haha. 

I personally 100%'d the game, with the help from a guide. If you are stuck don't take shame in using a guide, one of the chests is in my honest opinion incredibly hard to find. 

I found the battle system simple but satisfying, and the weapon/armor system, which is necessary to use for progress, was never too annoying other than the interaction between upgrades and equips. Remember to unequip your armor and weapons if you want to upgrade them!

The game is relatively easy until the last boss. I can't believe beating that on the highest difficulty is even possible, but if you're a masochist give it a go.

The story is really enjoyable in  my honest opinion and despite the simplicity it's very effective. I felt pretty invested in the main story focus and by the end, I was pretty satisfied with it. 
Some might find the story inconclusive, if so, Eternal Senia has a sequel! It's a tapping mobile game which I have also played. Do I recommend that game? If you really liked Eternal Senia give it a shot, but it being a tapping game gets tiring.

I really like Eternal Senia. I find it unique among other RPGMaker titles, and I find it very approachable in both gameplay and story. Recommend to anyone who wants to try a fresh RPG maker experience.

an absolute masterpiece. infinite fun-to-price ratio.

first of all, this game's story beats a lot of whatever trash hollywood is putting out these days, especially when you consider that the creator is just some indie programmer. i mean, yeah, it's got its sappy moments and cliches, but who doesn't these days? definitely enjoyed this more than trashy films like cars 3 or skyfall or dunkirk or emoji movie or anything by adam sandler (except 50 first dates, i don't mind that one).
the story follows a young girl named senia (hence the title) who ventures into a dangerous tower to try to rescue her sister magaleta (who is a nun for some reason) who has also ventured into this dangerous tower for reasons that you'll eventually learn about. she meets some friends along the way and along the way learns about her sister's mysterious past. i know it's a simple premise, but the end also hits hard with a message once you get there. oh, speaking of which, there are multiple endings. how to get them? that's something you're going to have to figure out yourself :^) senia's love for her sister is truly admirable. but how she expresses so is also part of the game's experience(TM) -  senia's really quite sweet. she also has a subtly distinct personality (unlike ANYONE adam sandler plays). there are also hidden secrets throughout the map and rewards for achieving certain things ;)

gameplay-wise, this game appears to have been designed to be accessible to all players, though seasoned RPG veterans will also find the game appealing. you attack enemies by walking into them, and press certain buttons to use special moves that are useful for both solving the puzzles in the game and defeating tougher enemies. there's also collectible items and upgradeable weapons, but what i appreciate about it is that there are pretty linear upgrades and equipment to achieve, meaning that you don't necessarily have to explore all these weird "different but not necessarily better" weapons that plague other RPGs (i'm looking at you, nier automata and final fantasy). the character equipment customization is simple and straightforward. 

oh something important to note: once you leave a section of the game's world, you can't go back to it, so make sure you've done everything you've wanted to do there before leaving. this was an interesting design choice, as it really adds to the mystery of the tower and lostness that senia may feel as she's walking through the levels. the game revolves around an overall theme of locked-in fate. it also plays like a dream - we watch senia progress through all these surreal places and yet once you leave one part of the "dream" you can't return to it. overall, it gives the game a demure and surreal atmosphere that will have you thinking about the game as you fall asleep that night.

the graphics? they're quaintly retro, if i must say myself. they also feed into the overall feeling of surrealness, what with their dreamlike representations of the forest, etc. the maps in this game are kind of cleverly structured in that the rooms' design never feel FORCED - like do you ever play a game where it's just a big room and there are just enemies randomly scattered throughout the room for no reason? (again, looking at you final fantasy. you introduce this big library or something and for some reason there's this random big room with like 10 chimeras and 5 bats and ZERO books. that doesn't make sense. also, pokemon ruby and sapphire. why are these 10 year old pokemon trainers all standing in a row waiting for you to enter their line of sight? it doesnt make much sense. eternal senia actually makes sense in this regard).

the game also is appreciably not very long. i finished it in about 5.5 hours. grand theft auto 5 is to 3 seasons of some korean drama as eternal senia is to a spin-off anime movie about, idk, some high school kids who swap bodies or something. you don't need a whole lot of commitment to finish this game, so if you havin' trouble committing to your significant other or don't have a significant other there to waste your time with, then this game should be some great fun.

i hope u are able to find the secret room ;) 

i rate this game an 8/10

82524623.review:
It feels bad to be among the 3-4% of players who vote this game negatively, but this is what the personal review system is for, right?
I was playing the game because it got recommended me in the discovery queue at a point, and at a point I added it to my library; and because I am participating in an event where you're supposed to play the top rated games of your library - and Eternal Senia was in the top few unplayed ones with its 97% longterm review-rate. So I needed to finish it.

As a forerunner - the game is not bad. Has ups and downs, and a lot of lukewarm mish-mash ...filler-quality stuff to it. Knowing what the game is I'd never have added it to my library. I wouldn't recommend it to my friends because it lacks a solid backbone to enjoy, it's more like a timesink. If you have more time, different taste - you may like it.

So, about the game:
I liked the music. Despite being super short and looping, the menu theme is pretty cool. Again, sorry - but a tune this catchy would deserve a game with more content. Other music during the game were quite distinct (especially the ones played during boss fights) and the sound effects were pretty good as well. Combat sounds effects OK.

Graphics is a bit of mixed bag, feels better than standard RPG-Maker sprites, but nothing really outstanding. I don't know if the spell and lightning effects were original, but they were used pretty well for the most time. Environments were varied (3 different chapters) but really barren at many points, and there is just nothing much going on. It's an ARPG with 2-3 characters that you don't fight with, and it was made with RPG-Maker as the dev's first game project, 

And for that, they did a pretty good job, with the tools they've got. The combat is a real YMMV thing - it's grindy but easy, so it's either laidback and chill (I felt this way) or repetitive and meaningless, as others felt. The item system was sadly pretty horrible, upgrading a worn item can require up to 30-40 button presses because it needs to be unequipped, then in a submenu of a submenu of a menu you need to scroll though a list of all possible recipes to upgrade it, then go back and re-equip it. 

 As I said, it feels weird to criticise someone's first attempt, but as the game is on Steam and in public, it can't get a universal pass. My main issue with the game is that it's - feels like admittedly, based on its description - a fanfiction-game of some characters from an MMO, and even ignoring the grammatical problems (It was painful to read "sis" a few hundred times, like a reminder if you'd ever forget who is the girl the protagonist nonstop talks about, despite never being present), it's a repetitive, cringey, anime-tropey story. There are barely any dialogue to be found, only monologues. 
There are I guess multiple pages worth ramblings about " I relied on you, but I want to help, I'm independent, where are you" from a character who's avatar is constantly blushing and/or crying. 
[spoiler] And in the true ending she does her  best to convince her sister Magaleta - from not sacrificing herself - that she needs her because not mature or independent enough[/spoiler]   I... feel like the dev wanted to make a damsel in distress waifu-character from the MMO the strong protagonist of the  game, but also keeping her original, timid personality because that's what they originally liked. I may be very wrong about this as I did not play Ragnarok Online, but the representation and the personality that is "presented" is jarringly different.

So, all in all I am quite baffled how this game has 97% review rates, and in a way I feel super cheated by the premise of this game being *that* good. It's okay, but it's a far, far cry in quality from the 95+ % games that people actually paid for.
Looks like it being free really gives a lot to it review score, I think it's in league with other games that are in the "mixed" review category. If you're on verge, treat it like so.

82287507.review:
Really enjoyed this.  The combat system is a great novelty.  It's gradually developed with the addition of extra skills and monsters with new abilities.  Some may find it repetitive, but I think this is mainly because each dungeon is structured similarly and the plot is quite simple.  I'd happily play a longer game still based on this mechanic, just with more variety in the storyline.  As well as fighting monsters and solving a few puzzles, you can craft new equipment by using the items you collect - it's a simple system but still satisfying. 

The game has its flaws.  The translation is full of grammar mistakes, but you can still work out what the sentence was meant to say.  The endings weren't great, since the characters' motivations for acting as they did weren't really clear.  Upgrading equipment is a little clunky because you have to go into a different menu and unequip the item first - but I've seen a lot worse.  For a game that is both short and free, these weren't big issues.

With a price tag of zero, the game is definitely worth a look.  I wish there were more like it!

82248870.review:
I think the dev did a really good job of putting an unusual spin on an RPG maker game to turn it into an ARPG. It's obviously a passion project, and the dev should be proud of seeing it through to completion. Making it available for free is very generous. I particularly liked the soundtrack. It's a great accomplishment, and the dev should feel proud.

That said, I don't recommend it because I don't think it's worth the time. If you don't have anything to play, sure, play through it - it's fine. But if you have a backlog, I'd go through that first.

The writing is full of typos and grammatical errors - and while I can overlook a little, having them appear in almost every single conversation becomes distracting. 

The inventory system is cumbersome - as an example, upgrading an item requires having to go into a sub-menu, un-equiping the item, backing out to the main menu, going into a different sub-menu, scrolling to find the item, upgrading the item, backing out again, going into the first sub-menu, and finally equipping the item again. Same for having to combine pages into a book and getting kicked out of the menus, such that you have to go back in to actually read the book.

The combat, while initially novel, quickly grows stale and boring in everything besides boss fights - and even most of the lesser boss fights are just spamming one button over and over. Levels likewise become really repetitive.

And the story is... acceptable? The writing was needlessly repetitious, re-stating the same thing over and over, and I found the characters to be very flat. The ending was the best part, if predictably melodramatic, but getting to the ending was kind of a chore. It is also sometimes unintentionally amusing, such as: "Sis curse resistance is surprisingly low. Her curse resistance is lower than normal."

This is a really cute and fun game for what it does.

Here's the breakdown:
Gameplay: If you know what you're doing, it's easy.
Leveling: Simple enough.
Story: This is where this game shines. One of my favorite lines is "Share with me!" I found that to be so adorable. (They were talking about problems and troubles.) The main character, Senia, brute forces her way through situation after situation. Unlike most childlike main characters, Senia prefers to force her way through. Her objective is selfish; to get her sister back because she doesn't want to be left out. Her motivation is childish, but that's what makes her so great. In the very first stage of the game, she encounters a locked door. When this happens, you'd think, "NOW WE NEED TO FIND A KEY!?" Senia brought her own though.

Overall:
This game is free. There's no reason not to play it.

My game time is more than most since I've enjoyed this game multiple times.

78979264.review:
Got this mentioned by a friend (can't remember if it was recommended?) but anyway. I tried it, and beat it. I must say, for a free game, this is pretty good.

There is a couple things that could be polished, especially on the graphical side, a couple of characters seem to have very different styles. The big bosses are cool though, even if they don't fit at all with the other small character's style, I think it's a good effect and I accept it as variety. 

The scenarios were kind of cheaply done however, some I feel were pretty much copy-pasted, and some were just blatant extensions to a couple parts of the game (like in the final area, you see no corridor between two zones, but try going to the right and a magical long boring corridor comes into existence).

The story was good, it wasn't super spectacular but it was more about the characters and their relationship. I'm not much into moving stories but I think they feel believable and I like them. I feel some of the dialogues sound a bit weird, probably due to the translation, which is overall good enough, but yeah a couple of sentences sound very weird (I must say, I'm not a native English speaker either, but since the game is in English I prefer to do the review in English too).

Now, to the good things, because yeah this has some. The art of characters is super cute, it really outshines even some of the other probably standard assets the developer used. The menus also look very good, and are simple to use. I actually think some menus could have a facelift too, like the equip and inventory screens, since they seemed to have a slightly different style to things like the main party screen and the skills screen. But anyway this is me being picky.

Another thing I felt very solid was the gameplay. The game is on the easy side, might even be on the very easy side. This is the author's intention anyway as they mention somewhere in the game the game is intended to be playable by anyone, and there is also a couple "challenges" thrown in the mix, I beat one of the bosses in that challenge mode, and I enjoyed it, it wasn't frustrating neither easy. If you like hard games, you might want to just beat all monsters in the hard mode though, and see if that's enough for you.

One problem on gameplay I found though is that some enemies feel like filler. They do irrelevant damage, and alone they can't do anything to you either. They are greatly outshined by other enemies with more interesting skills, such as ranged, charge attacks or spell casting, who can actually be a treat to you and ask you to do something. The other guys are just dead meat to farm the items for the crafting system. Which by the way is there, it's fine, nothing great but it's at least straight to the point.

Overall I'd say it's a nice little game, I enjoyed playing it.

77050609.review:
With this game, you get more than you pay for. Yes, I realize it's a free game, but most free games either have long grinds, pay-to-win, obnoxious ads, poor pacing, etc. This game has none of that. The grinds are short, never more than a few minutes at a time, no ads or required DLC, just a simple story to be told at a decent pace.

The graphics are well done, the music is great, though not always suitable to the situation at hand, and the game's story doesn't get complicated or unintelligible; it's not a story about saving the world, just saving the one person that means the most to you. The translations need help, but are still able to be understood, so it's not "All Your Base Are Belong To Us" level of translation problems.

There's a rare bug, where if you kill certain elite monsters that drop a finite quantity item at the same time they kill you, the drop despawns and you have no way to get the final weapon and armor as a result, and you'll be short at least one other final tier upgrade. This happens because these creatures do not cause Game Over, but instead continue you back at the nearest entrance. It's easy enough to just reload your game, but make sure you don't accidentally save while in this condition.

Aside from that, this is a short game, so there's not a lot of content, but the amount of content feels right for the amount of game that's here. You'll be getting new armor and weapons on a steady pace, about 4 weapons and 12 armor about every 90-120 minutes, so it feels pretty constant. Same with the skills, you get one with about the same regularity as the weapons and armor.

If you're looking to kill a few hours, this game offers enough to be satisfying at least once though. This game shows that the developer has a lot of potential, so I do hope that they decide to assemble a small team (including an English speaker) and make a larger project. I imagine that with a few more people helping, the Senia universe could be expanded and made in to a grand adventure.

Well, what can I say? It's OK. Not great, not bad either.

The story is really short. It's an RPG, but I think you're meant to be playing it as if it's an Arcade game, ignoring a few of its RPG elements. The game has more than 1 endings, but all of them can be achieved in mere minutes after the first playthrough.

All that's left is one thing: You're not supposed to finish this game like other RPGs. You're supposed to play it like an Arcade Hack-and-Slash game while treating the story like an afterthought. While this will usually receive a thumbs-down from me, the fact is, the game is FREE and you're very welcome to try it yourself, so that's already a great thing.

73303092.review:
Forgive me in advance for the lack of details - I played this game about 4 years ago and only recently decided to leave reviews for games I personally recommend. Games that deserve it. This is one.

I never played RO which the developer was inspired by, but my teenage (and current) self found the story deeply moving. It is very easy to become heavily invested in the characters, which is further complemented by the excellent gameplay and aesthetics. The characters are adorable but not tropey (strong female protagonist!) with wonderfully crafted scenes and illustrations. The combat system is unique and satisfying without being too complicated, which combined with great puzzles and enemies and everything else makes for an amazing game well worth experiencing.

The developer put a lot of love into this game and was skilled enough to make it truly shine in ways many AAA titles couldn't even dream of. I originally picked it up because it was free and looked nice, but now I see it as something I'd pay for the pleasure of enjoying again. Play it now, thank me (and mainly the developer) later. Speaking of which, if there is a way to support them, perhaps consider if you think they deserve it. Personally I think we need more stuff like this in the world.

I don't really play a lot of RPGs or ARPGs, but I got to give credit for this game because not only they have released this on Steam, they've manage to make it simple enough to catch my interest and light enough for my Smashed Potato PC to be able to play it. This'll be my first time writing a review but this game is atleast deserve one:

[h1] GRAPHICS [/h1]
Its a Pixelated Game, ofc graphics cannot almost be measure but considering a lot of pixelated games are starting to feel smooth; This one is a bit outdated, but considering the game's release date, from a scale of 1-5
its a 3. ofc its an indie game but a lot will develop.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
ARPGs are not my thing but it let me captures my interest and let play for at least a solid 5 hours. It was different especially the controls. I played a lot of MOBAs and I was fortunate the controls for the skills are somewhat similar, but I want it to be customizable. Its simple but at the same time too linear so I don't want replay it multiple times because it is also grindy even though they have created a system to lessen the time of farming up: The Arcade. Lastly, there are a lot of exploitable bugs and glitches which are not game breaking but they let the game play easier and clear the Big guys a lot quicker

[h1] SOUND [/h1]
Special effects are loud but appropriate to what they're pertaining to its effects, The music is lovely especially the piano part.

[h1] STORY [/h1]
The story heartwarming and cold, it captures the love of siblings even though they are not sisters in blood and at the same time the the devastation a power within a Tower can bring. Its a simple concept and I do like that they will continue it as a mobile game and pushing development further as an indie game.

Juego increíble para ser gratuito... Una historia muy bien cuidada que te engancha hasta acabarlo (y te saca bastante lágrimas :-) ) 

Es un juego para todos los públicos, ya que es un juego sencillo de avanzar, aunque si se quiere un poco más de dificultad, el juego te da la opción de elegir los jefes finales en modo "difícil" que sí exigen un poco más al jugador. Además tienes la opción de intentar conseguir todos los "secretos" y tiene 3 finales diferentes que hace que se alargue un poco el juego. (5 horas de un juego gratuito, y sin que se haga pesado, significa que hay que jugarlo sí o sÍ).

En cuanto al estilo de juego, tienes el ataque estándar y 4 ataques especiales que se van desbloqueando conforme avanza la historia. En cuanto a personalización del personaje, es más bien escasa, ya que tienes unos atributos predefinidos que se pueden mejorar con libros que se consiguen en cofres o venciendo a enemigos. Además las armas y armaduras posibles son muy pocas (una pieza de cada por zona con 4 niveles de calidad). Sería quizás el punto más flojo del juego, que se centra sobre todo en la historia.

Por lo que respecta al aspecto artístico, los gráficos son aceptables para este tipo de juegos (por supuesto no tiene los gráficos de un AAA), y la música está muy cuidada con diferentes cambio para ajustarse a la ambientación y son melodías bastante agradables. No he encontrado bugs.

En definitiva, la valoración es altamente positiva ya que la historia engancha y hará que se te pase el tiempo volando.Muy recomendable y con ganas de una segunda parte, que supongo que será de pago, pero se lo merece.

I'm looking for games with meaningful stories and characters.
The issue this game is about is pretty primitive and both sisters are unbelievably [spoiler]foolish[/spoiler]. 

Here's a very brief summary (including the 3rd ending):
[spoiler]
Magaleta lost her sister and at a later point found Senia and now had a new sister

Magaleta went to the Tower of Eternity in the first place to get Senia's curse lifted, because she didn't want to see her die too... sure that's nice and all, but in this case it seems Magaleta ran from what would happen. I mean, she left her dying... and she wouldn't see it if it happened. Good solution.

In the end Magaleta realizes that and also tells Senia she has matured a lot, but instead of accepting that, Senia claims she hasn't over and over demanding her sister to keep protecting her... and then Magaleta dies.  And to make that meaningful, Senia swears to try again (how??) to save her... even though she knows Magaleta wouldn't want that. I mean, mourning a loss would be fine, but she clearly can't get over it. It's not "determination". She is clearly dependent and delusional.

So it all happened because both characters are incredibly... Oh well, what a tragedy.[/spoiler]


I suppose you might like the game if you can relate to that kind of characters.
I cannot.

70069624.review:
I wish steam had an option for neutral reviews... It's not particularly bad, but it's not great at anything it does either (though as others have pointed out the soundtrack is good)

The game makes use of extremely simple mechanics (you basically walk into enemies) and bosses have some area of effect attacks that you need to dodge. I might have given it a positive review if it weren't for the crazy difficulty spike at the last boss (every other boss at that point had never given me any issues). 

Now I'm not one to shy away from challenge, but it felt like a lot of the times I died were due to clunky controls, I get what the developer was trying to go for in that last fight (and I did it on hard because I figured maybe there would be a special bonus if I beat all the bosses on hard, there wasn't).

In terms of story, it's not bad but it's nothing special either, you play as Senia, a girl who's trying to save her older sister from the tower of eternity. Throughout the game you learn a bit about their backstory and events leading up to the game.

The game implies a sequel, and I'll admit if the developer can fix some of the clunkyness I'd consider playing it for the right price (the sequel looks like it should have more characters as well so that could potentially work to it's advantage)

That being said I know a lot of people did like this game, so if the clunky controls don't bug you then give it a go, not like it will cost you anything.

68816723.review:
**Before reading this review, please keep in mind that this is MY opinion and shouldn't affect how other people view this game**
This is my second time trying to write this review since when I first tried to post this review, Steam for some reason didn’t post it and I lost it T.T
So, I found this game while browsing for some new RPG games to play (since I’ve been having an urge to play some), and I came across this one. I decided to give it a shot since it said it was an overwhelming positive game and that it was an RPG game. The story is about a girl named Senia who goes to the Tower of Eternity to go search for her sister, Magaleta. Now, one thing I can say about this game is that I really ended up enjoying it! I don’t regret playing it one bit! It was really fun and there were a lot of things I enjoyed about it, which I will now mention.
1.	The music! From the beginning when I started this game, this was one of the first things that stood out to me. Just the intro music felt so relaxing yet so upbeat at the same time, it felt like the type of music you would listen to in order to give yourself some motivation. As the game progressed, I liked how the soundtrack sounded. I felt like the music matched what the ambience was portraying, and it made me feel my emotions intensify with the feeling coming across. 
2.	Character design/the art pieces: This also stood out to me around the time I started the game, I really like the character designs for the characters (for both Senia and Magaleta). Like I really like how cute they looked without taking it too over the top that it…couldn’t be taking seriously (?) The design for the bosses were also pretty cool, and I especially liked the art pieces of Senia and Magaleta that were done for endings, I thought those looked amazing and it just made my emotions accentuate while looking at them.
3.	How the layout seems pretty direct. You know those types of games where you are just left confused as to where to go, where most of your time is spent finding where to go? Well, that’s not the type of game this is. I really liked how the layout was pretty direct. You were either going in a straight line, or there were certain moments where you had to look around, but finding your way was still pretty easy. And it was nice since it helped progress the story way faster by doing that.
4.	How they tell you that they recommend you to save before the final boss. If you’re like me, you’re probably the type of person who rushes into things to the point that you forget to save sometimes. With this game, they actually give you a warning when you’re about to face a boss and that they recommended me to save. It made me stop and think, “Oh wait, I should probably save before going on ahead”. 
5.	The fact that they give you the option on what mode you would like to use for each enemy. Before facing the enemy, you are given the option of what mode you would like to use. Depending on how you confident you feel, you can either go for easy or hard. In my case,  I really liked this since it gave me an opportunity to beat the story without stressing too much (I played mostly on easy, and though I did try hard mode, I didn’t get very far, but I think for players who want more of a challenge, that is the way to go). 
6.	Similar to the previous one, I also liked that they didn’t force you to fight all the enemies if you didn’t want to: Sure, there were some enemies that you had to face, but for example, going into the Arcane realm was more of a choice. If you wanted to upgrade your gear and get all those materials, but if you didn’t want to, you didn’t have to. You could also evade some of the enemies you walked into if you didn’t feel like facing all of them which was nice as it felt like I could choose my own battles (and well, in my case, it was nice I wasn’t forced to face the King enemies, cause the times I tried were pretty annoying).
7.	The different endings. Well, one thing that usually impacts a lot on a game is how good the endings are. With this game, I liked how each ending gave a different feel. While ending 1 did feel kind of sad with a little sense of enjoyment to it, I liked how you needed to do more (and see things you didn’t see before previous to getting ending 2 and 3). Ending 2 added a bit of a hopeless touch to it (Seeing the more negative emotions), and ending 3, while being really sad, added a more hopeful glint to the story, which was really nice (And to be honest, ending 3 was the one who almost made me cry).
8.	The last thing I would like to bring up from the things I like is the character development. While it wasn’t something too major, it did felt nice to see how Senia changed (growing stronger from the beginning of the game). Like especially when you see the ending, you see how her personality and how she views Nia also changes, as she comes to accept how Magaleta views her. I also like the personality of Magaleta, how you see all she has been through, being so hopeless at trying to save people she loves, yet failing, and how it comes across that she really does care about Senia, but not being too overly dotting, as you do see her scold Senia when she does something bad.

But well, even though I really liked this game, I cannot say it is perfect (To be honest, I don’t think any game can be truly perfect). So now that I have mentioned all I like, now I am going to mention the things that I didn't like:
1. The game's story/the plot: Now, especially with what I said before, it may seem contradictory that I say something bad about the plot. I did like how they progressed the story, but i just feel that the whole thing of a character going to save a loved one is a bit cliche and it feels overused. Like when I saw that in the beginning, I was like "Another game like that?" however, they did make up for it with the turns, but still.
2. The enemies and how precise your positioning had to be sometimes for an attack to go through: Now this doesn't have to do with normal enemies you encounter, but with the bosses. I didn't like that you had to be in an exact spot in order for the attack to hit, I felt that was rather stupid, since in the end, you would still be able hit an enemy even if you are a little bit more to the left (logically speaking)

But yeah, overall, I really enjoyed this game. It had a good story, nice characters, the battles were also nice (the fact that it wasn't just about offense, but you also needed to evade attacks, as well). The bosses looked pretty nice too! The game is not too long either, so it's worth looking into.
So, final thoughts? I would definitely recommend this game to anybody who likes a bit of fighting, and especially considering its free, I would say, give it a shot! In my opinion, you won't regret it, at least for me it wasn’t.

68801287.review:
TL;DR I like it a lot.

This is probably one of my favourite F2P games on Steam so I'm going to come off a bit bias.

To be fair, I was sort of off-putted by the game's graphics in a couple of the game's screenshots. The clipped images in the attack animations and the static bosses were ehh... But while playing through the game, I got used to it -- in a good way! It's charming and gives off that mid-2000s flash game feel.

Everything else though... where do I start?

The combat is simple, yet satisfying. Though there is no "basic attack button," I don't think that oversimplifies gameplay or make it boring at all. First of all, the game makes use of the standard 3 normal abilities, 1 ulti that you pretty much see in every game nowadays, and for good reason -- it works. Second of all, your auto attack is animated and there is a slight buffer between finishing a swing and moving. So in that sense, there is actually some micro management involved. That is, feeling for her attack animation delay, properly using her abilities at the right time, etc. etc.

Crafting and equipment upgrades are pretty straightforward too. You enter a stage, collect some craftables, make some stuff, upgrade that stuff, then toss it aside when you enter a harder stage with better craftables. It keeps to the theme of simplicity, and makes it super satisfying to progress.

You'll either at most really like the gameplay for how simple and standard it is, or at least feel indifferent about it for the exact same reasons.

Similarly for the plot, at most you'll love it if you're a sap for simple, "trying not to reinvent the wheel" anime plots, or at least you'll be cringing/indifferent because it's one of those run-off-the-mill shonens. (I'd read it if it were a light novel.)

However, I think the OST and the art speak for itself. They're undeniably beautiful.

If you're an anime fan, definitely try it out. The game's simple enough for anyone at any "gamer level" to experience the story/art/OST. Plus, there's an easy difficulty (though I haven't personally tried it myself).

But that isn't to say the game isn't hard. I spent a good deal on the "final boss," and the final boss. I can't imagine what it'd be like on hard difficulty.

Alright, that's it.

68373681.review:
This was an unexpected favourite.

I remember downloading and booting up this game a very long time ago, playing maybe a minute or so and then not touching it until now. I think I figured it would be like most indie RPGs in that style and simply prioritized other games for a while. But once I clicked on it again the other day, I had to play through the whole thing. It's just so much [i]fun[/i]. Now, my opinions are coming from a place of someone unfamiliar with which assets were made from scratch for this game and which were borrowed, so keep that in mind.

[b]PROS[/b]

[list]
[*] The action gameplay. This is the game's strongest pillar and it holds up all throughout. When I first laid eyes on this game, I didn't expect it to be an action RPG, nor did I expect it to be so fun and simple. It's definitely easy, but not in a bad way. It's straightforward, easy to learn, smooth and keeps evolving further in as you discover more attack patterns and skills. Considering the graphic and movement limits of a game like this, the dev did a stellar job on this battle system. There's also some crafting involved which was pretty fun to grind for.

[*] The music. This is a sad game and the soundtrack really helps strengthen the emotional aspects without being too overbearing. It's not just "here's the sad music that's telling you it's time to be sad," it's genuinely good music as well.

[*] The art. The portrait art is quite good but especially so are the boss visuals. Whenever a big boss appeared I loved looking at the sheer size of them and the details on their designs.

[*] The characters and narrative. It's not a complicated story nor is it in any way long, but I felt for the protagonist and wanted her to succeed. At no point did I feel like it was getting boring or uninteresting, but rather wanted to know more about the characters the more I played.[/list]

[b]CONS[/b]

[list]
[*]The grammar. It was in no way a deal breaker for me as I could perfectly understand the dialogue and what it wanted to convey, but it did leave some hiccups here and there in the overall experience. For example, at an especially emotional scene they used the word "hurted" instead of "hurt" which made me laugh rather than cry.[/list]

And that's about it. I would say that it's too short but at the same time I feel like it's just as short as it needed to be. I just enjoyed it to the extent where I would have liked to play more.

I first played this game about 4 or 5 years ago at a friend's recommendation, and absolutely loved it. I've been having an itch to play it again these past few days, and I finally did so today. Funnily enough, I only remembered one of the game's endings, and even then it was a very vague recollection.

All in all, I'm REALLY glad that I came back and played the game again. For anyone worried about game length or pacing, don't worry. It paces very well and is very fluid and smooth. The *only* thing I can consider as a 'negative point' about this game is that there are some translation errors, but they're minor issues only, and nothing that would cause any misunderstandings about the game, its plot, character names, etc.

In this day and age (April, 2020) where gameplay, difficulty, and complex button combinations seem to reign supreme in the Action genre, it's extraordinarily refreshing to come back and play through such a fun game with very simple controls and mechanics. Simple, still enjoyable. So thank you, Sanctum Games. Thank you for such a great game - and I'm looking forward to the sequel!

67454774.review:
I will update this review later with a full review after I get my YouTube video up, but I will say a few short words for now.


I don't want to sound too harsh reviewing a game that is free, but honestly this game came up short in every aspect for me, save one: The soundtrack. 

The music for this game is amazing.  I love the intro song and all the songs throughout make the game bearable.  That, for me, is where the positive credit ends.

The game mechanics were a good concept: simple, intuitive, smooth.  However, the implementation missed the mark.  That is actually how I feel about a lot of the aspects of this game.  It is like the creator had all these great concepts kicking around in his head and he got really excited about getting them into a game, so he just threw everything out there and didn't take the time to refine it. 

The story line is a bit cliche and predictable, which is okay for the style game, but honestly the poor translation to English really made it hard for me to feel immersed in the story.  I'm not talking small, simple missed words.  The whole game is stiff and garbled, making it nearly impossible to even figure out what the characters are trying to say at times, let alone causing me to feel any empathy for them.

The leveling system is straight forward, but a bit tedious.  You only gain 1 attack, 1 defense, and some HP every time you level up, so it doesn't really feel rewarding.  Leveling the skills up definitely scales the damage they do, though, but the SP required ramps up a lot so you eventually hit a point of diminishing returns.

The combat system was a cool idea, but it isn't very well implemented.  Sometimes your Area of Effect attack will hit the enemies in front of you, sometimes it won't.  It seemed like the hit-box was determined by where the sprites were located at the end of their movement rather than the beginning.  So the attack may have already hit, but since your attack animation is still up, if a monster walks into it then it will still count it as a hit. Not very well polished, but forgivable to an extent for a free game. I think what bothered me the most, honestly, is that there was not enough variety in boss attacks and even just regular monster attacks.  The indicators were nice, but some attacks did damage the entire time the sprite was active while others only did when it first appeared.  Some did damage if you moved around while being hit but not if you stood still, and others did the opposite even with similar attack types.

The developer started to introduce fun little puzzles (kind of like in Lufia II for SNES) but then just... stopped.  There were maybe three in the whole game and they were all solvable without any effort or intention put into the problem.  One of those "If you aren't going to flush it out to its full potential then just get rid of it" situations for me. 

On a scale of 1-9 I would say this game gets a 3 for me. I feel a little conflicted, as I said, because it is obvious that the creator had a lot of passion and care in creating the game and I DO appreciate that, but I am reviewing the game, not the creator's heart. 

to Holy Priest: let me know if you are interested/willing to redo the English translation. If you can send me a file that has all the different speech sections in it, I don't mind going through and fixing the grammatical errors to make it more appealing to your English speaking audience.  

Keep up your efforts and don't be dissuaded by my review. You definitely have the potential here for a great game, it just needed more polish.

66801590.review: I love RPGs, and by extension I'm a big-time player of RPG Maker games, so of course when I saw how many positive reviews this one had combined with its low, low price of $0, I was inclined to download it. But... even though it's free, I still gotta criticize it, especially as an aspiring maker of free RPG Maker games myself. I am baffled that this has so many positive reviews, because I couldn't find a single thing to like about it - everything had already been done better in another game. Almost all the assets were base RPG Maker assets except the sprites of the major characters, and the "battles" had absolutely no strategy and became incredibly tedious as you just run into enemies over and over again and hope for the best. I'm absolutely willing to live with bad gameplay if there's a good story (I love Dangan Ronpa and lord are some of those class trial minigames awful), but despite the rave reviews the story has from many reviews, I really couldn't get into it. Of course, I didn't finish the game, but the translation was so stiff and unnatural and the characters so two-dimensional and cliched that I don't think I would have gotten more into it even had I powered through the tedium and reached the end. I'm really sorry, and I know there are a lot of people out there who must have gotten something out of this game, but unfortunately, I was not one of them.

66774318.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#423 out of 612)... it's time for Eternal Senia.

Another game with a weird title that exists in my library, and I have no idea why I decided to get it in the first place. Presumably it was recommended to me as one of the better free-to-play JsRPGs on Steam. But, well, if that was the case... I can't say I agree.

My time with Eternal Senia has not been long, but I think I've got a sufficient grasp of the combat system—and it's very much not my thing. It's not really turn-based or real-time combat, not in the traditional sense. It's more like a shallow imitation of the infamous "bump system" of Ys I and Ys II: you simply walk around the world and bump into enemies as they deal damage to you, and you them. It's not very interesting or engaging. 

Perhaps most damningly, Eternal Senia doesn't support gamepad controls [i]or[/i] mouse controls, leaving me completely baffled at how a keyboard-only game could possibly exist outside of the very early 1990s. The narrative framing the action likewise did little to capture my interest. It's a free game, so it's probably worth giving a shot (not like you'll lose out on anything but time) but, personally, Eternal Senia didn't quite do enough for me to justify giving it a recommendation here.

65982603.review:
I never like giving a free game a negative review, especially ones that the developer clearly put effort into, but welp.

I'm too lazy to make up cohesively summarize my thoughts, so here's a lost of good n' not-so-good:

Good:

- Likeable protagonist, and nice anime-style art and cutscenes.
- Good music.
- The typical RPG treadmill of acquiring goop to make yourself more powerful could be satisfying at times.
- Localized in Japanese (a rarity among free RPG Maker games, at least on Steam).
- Bosses could be challenging sometimes, if you battled them with somewhat under-leveled gear.

Bad or okay:

- The story is only passable and I did not appreciate the cutscene interruptions a whole lot. Though it did still tugged at my heart-strings a few times.
- Bland, static-feeling environments due to being RPG Maker-based.
- The crafting system's progression was boring. You have different weapon/armor slots, each of which had a few sets of armor with different tiers you could craft your way up to (with each tier requiring the previous-tier armor as a crafting ingredient), but progressing your armor was all about grinding ingredients from mobs. It also got tiresome having to take off a given piece of armor before being able to craft with it. And it didn't help that most of the armor categories used the same sprite, making everything blend together.
- A lot of the game felt like it was using stock RPG Maker assets. For example, many enemies feel like generic JRPG enemies, and the bosses in the game are just giant, static sprites that don't really feel like they fit in with the rest of the game.
- Later portions of the game started to feel a bit wacky to me, suddenly introducing stuff like a Pac-Man-ish minigame.
- As I progressed in the game, I didn't have any interesting decisions to make: I attacked enemies that could barely damage me, I grinded for crafting goop, and I did janky and rudimentary puzzles and increasingly just felt wacky and out-of-place.
- Character development didn't work for me, and I found myself questioning if any of the characters' motives or disposition towards me was believable.

All in all, it looks and kinda feels like a SNES RPG, but it lacks the magic and production values that make me love the genre.

EDIT: To name some names, anything by Zeboyd are good examples of contemporary games that both capture the magic of older JRPGs while at the same time also introducing their own twists. So I'd recommend checking out Breath of Death, Cthulhu Saves the World, and Cosmic Star Heroine on Steam. With the former 2 being super cheap but yet still very high quality games.
