Okay, so I'd just like to say I picked this up on a whim, saw it recommended and I decided to give it ago. 
I don't think I have ever been so glad to pick up a game before. The story is absolutely spectacular. It's not complicated, but not really cliche either. It's well, touching. Don't have any other way to describe it. The gameplay is simple and intuitive and does not get repetitive (due to the shorter length of the game). It's not grindy at all, unless you decide to go for endings 2 and 3, in which case you'll have to farm for the best gear (took me around 20 mins on top of the rest of the stuff). The final boss for endings 2 and 3 are pretty hard, and it'll take a few tries (with maxed gear) to get down the attack patterns. The low overall difficulty of the game makes it easy and not frustrating to power through in one sitting which is what I did. It also helps to keep the story at the forefront of your attention during the game, without feeling like a visual novel.
Again, I can't recommend this enough. If you stumble across this game, give it a try! It's free so it can't hurt.
One last thing - the music is superb.

57528975.review:
Well, I rarely write game reviews, but this game is damn special, and I have spent time convincing myself to write a review for it. 
To be honest, this game is not very prominent at the first glance, never heard of the developer before, and they only have this game on steam... we all know that appearance of a game on store page is important, as an interesting picture/video/name could attract more potential players.
But, we can only truly judge a game after we have played it. And after playing, the game is, simply put, PERFECTION.
The music carries the atmospheric emotion of sadness; the plot, although not mind-blowing, it gives players a deep feeling of bittersweetness when witnessing the sisterly love between Senia and Magaleta; the battle system strikes a balance between difficulty and enjoyment from defeating monsters...
I personally love games which incur strong emotion in people and opportunity to contemplate the meaning of something profound expressed in the game. In this case, it is a mixture of love, regret, self-doubting, and the determination. Nowadays in the real world where sick politics, profit-driven mindset and outrageous crimes take up chunks of news headlines, these qualities are rare to be found. It is touching to play such a masterpiece. 
And finally, there remains a question that we may have or not an answer to: in the time of crisis, are we determined to protect and save our beloved ones, and do we have power to do so?

57483367.review:
Talk about a gem. I didn't know I needed a cross between [i]Hydlide[/i] and [i]Ys[/i], but with tragic lesbians, yet here we are. As someone that messed about endlessly with early versions of RPGMaker from the 90s, I'm always really impressed when people push an already limiting system way past what it was originally designed for. [i]Eternal Senia[/i] definitely qualifies.

I mean, sure, the translation could use an edit, and I think the maps + tile sets could use more detail in places, but it really is enjoyable regardless, never overstays its welcome, and certainly worth more than its current price tag of free. Here's hoping the sequel eventually makes it to Steam; I can't be the only one curious to see where Senia and Magaleta's story may go.

[b]RATING:[/b] ★★★★

55287501.review: A very simple and easy game to play. I really love the "Ragnarok Online" aesthetics this game offers. Even the main character Senia is taken directly from the female swordsman class artwork in Ragnarok Online and is also considered to be based on a character in the game named Ygnizem Seniar. Even the description in the Steam page of this game says that it is inspired directly from Ragnarok Online. I don't know if this is considered plagiarism or not seeing that it was made by a fan of Ragnarok, but I still certainly love this game no matter what. Its kinda like those "Flash" fan games you find online, there not official and are simply made by fans, yet are still fun to play. I am a huge Ragnarok fan myself. I have watched my sibling play the original online game as a kid, and going back to to play it myself really feels nostalgic. I've also watched the Ragnarok anime, which is an old anime, but still a great adaptation of the game. So far, my favourite Ragnarok game is the spin-off game called "Ragnarok Odyssey Ace" for the PlayStation 3. I'm getting off-topic here, but the point is I love the Ragnarok series, and this game really feels like one. I'm not very good when it comes to strategy, but thankfully this game is easy to play. Plus this game is FREE, so its not like you're being ripped off or anything. Overall, I love this game, plagiarism or not.

Gameplay: 8/10

Dungeon explorer. Quite refreshing for me, and minimal grind required. Some hidden things too. 
However, the King monsters are too easy, literally just go up to them and spam Q. Also, who the hell can beat final boss hard mode anyways.

Graphics: 8/10

Its a bloody indie game. The graphics are very simplistic but they add to the charm of the story incredibly well.

Music: 10/10

Very thematically appropriate. Generally, the soundtrack alternated between suspenseful and calming menu themes. What else is there to say?

Overall: 11/10
Its free, damnit. 

Also, better prepare tissues.

54104702.review:
This game is a cute, anime-styled RPG with a variety of enemies, a coherent storyline, and lots of optional challenges for those who want it. No achievements, but it doesn't really need any. For the most part, everything is balanced...it just takes a bit of grinding. The music is always pretty fitting to the mood, and the levels are well-designed.

[i]HOWEVER[/i]

[b]THE FINAL BOSS[/b] (no spoilers) [b]IS RNG CANCER.[/b]
I dunno if it's because I'm playing on hard mode, but everything is random, everything kills you in a minimum of five hits with next to no i-frames, and your arena is super tiny, with the boss hitbox being only a single tile. This...is pretty bad. Not enough to give it a thumbs down, but close.

So yeah, it's free too, so go check it out.

EDIT:

After a very long time and many frustratingly close moments, I finally beat the final boss.
The ending hit me way harder than I had thought it would, making an amazing conclusion that almost makes that last fight worth it. Trying not to spoil it, it carried an very impactful message about love of family and determination. (For any who are interested, I got endings #2 and #3.) Looks like it's not over yet...time to play the sequel.

I ended up enjoying this game so much that when it disappeared from my library(twice and I forgot the name shame on me) I spent copious amounts of time trying to find it just so I could play it again. Sure, the pixel graphics aren't earth shattering, sure it's a bit simple but that's what makes it fun. Combat is engaging but not difficult, puzzles are interesting and add some thinking and nothing is TOO overdone. It's a simple, relaxing game that I'm PLEASED to see as I've come back now to see the reviews that it has developed a cult following of sorts. Love its linear structure, art etc. It doesn't try to be something that it isn't and succeeds at being what it is.

TL;DR it's a free, simple, and fun game with pretty art that you'll enjoy. It's free and that's a great price.

Writing this after beating the game 100%. 50848219.review:
Eternal Senia is a decent action RPG with a solid (if somewhat questionably-translated) storyline and excellent music, about the relationship between totally-not-Egnigem Cenia and her adoptive big sister, totally-not-Margaretha Sorin. It struggles a bit against the limits of the RPG Maker engine in making an action RPG, resulting in rather easy and mostly pointless combat against normal enemies, especially if you farm out the best equipment, but it still boasts a selection of eight or so interesting boss fights over its 3-5 hours of playtime.

Also, it's free, so if you're at all interested in it you should probably just pick it up. Recommended more for the story than for action RPG lovers, but the gameplay doesn't detract from the experience.

50499808.review:
This free to play gem seems like a combination of my favourite SNES-RPGs.

- you climb a tower and solve small puzzles like in Lufia 1&2 (Fortress of Doom, anyone?)
- your equipment and crafting material becomes obsolete once you enter a new stage and craft new, more advanced stuff from new materials (Secret of Evermore - 1995)
- realtime, semi-automatic combat with enemies walking around (reminded me of Zelda - 1991)

Tha crafting is pretty basic and most of the game world looks simple, which contradicts the beautiful character images. The puzzles were fun. I loved the music and couldn't get enough of it. The story, while having a few minor translation oddities, is heartwarming and very emotional.

This game deserves a price tag. Since it's free, you should really give it a try if you enjoy classics or rpg-maker games.
Now if you'll excuse me, I'll grap some tissues and listen to "Knockin on heavens door" - for no particular reason.

49709210.review:
I found Eternal Senia while browsing Steam and noticed it's amazing positive to negative review ratio. As you would expect I was a bit sceptical. When I first loaded into the game I had no idea what to expect and was a bit off put when I saw the graphics and screen resolution. However, after playing for 20 minutes the style definitely grew on me and I came to really like it. The plot was sweet and it felt really nice to finish all the endings and get all the items. There is a good balance of difficulty, especially with easy and hard options. If you're expecting Dark Soul level difficulty then this probably isn't the game for you. Hard mode sits in a spot where it can take a few (or many) tries to beat a boss, but it's not gonna take you hours for one boss. Overall everything in the Eternal Senia was amazingly well-rounded, with nothing feeling crazy good nor bad. It's a fun game to play when your tired or burnt out of other games. Not to mention the brilliant OST! Everything in Eternal Senia hits the mark dead on for a great game.

Pros:
~Simple mechanics
~Amazing OST
~A feel-good plot
~Good balance in difficulty (+options for easy and hard)
~Decent play time (~4 hours)
~Good artwork
~Multiple endings
~Translation for English (Huzzah!)
~Good power progression. There isn't really a point that you feel too undergeared or too overpowered, but when you do craft a new item you can feel a difference.

Cons:
~Graphics and screen resolution might be a turn off for some, however, I would recommend at least seeing if you get used to it after a bit.
~Occasional crash (I had about 2 while I was playing)
~The English translation is a bit choppy throughout, but definitely not unintelligible at any point.

Overall, Eternal Senia is a game that almost anyone can enjoy. It is just generally well made and I would recommend it for everyone to at least have a go!

I love classic style games like this. I will admit, I have a natural soft spot for anime styled games and especially for pixel-art style RPG games, but I can safely say that this game is one that is really well done.

Now, it did have a few problems with the English translation, but that didn't take away from the experience of the game at all. For me at least, it sort of added a bit of a connected feeling to the developer since I understand some of the trials of game development, having attempted it myself.

Overall, I loved this game (I still do). The story was well done, the artwork was done really nicely, the game mechanics were simple to understand with a very quick but easy enough learning curve, there were hidden bits in the levels that it took drawing upon my RPG secret-finding skills to find, and the controls were very easy to wrap my head around.

In conclusion, play this game. You will like it. Trust me.

49445876.review:
This recommendation comes with reservations.
I liked the flashstep attack. That was cool, especially when there were actually puzzles built around it. Sadly, I don't think the other abilities were as well thought out - particularly the last one.
Abilities aside, I liked the gameplay. I do wish the lower-leveled stat-boosting book pages were available on higher floors, and that there was something to do with all the leftover stuff I had by the end, but it didn't drag the thing down too much. A shop would have helped, though.

The translation had issues - I don't think it was edited by a native English speaker. The only times I had a real problem with it were at the boss fights (where the oddly-organized difficulty levels aren't entirely clear) and the heavy emotional moments, where the overlong text robbed some of the art's impact.

The art was serviceable for the most part, interesting for Senia herself, and unpleasantly sexual for the Fairy Queen, the Succubi, and a couple of other things.

I mostly liked the writing, but I did have a few issues.
*Incest vibes showed up late in the game, without warning or acknowledgement. I found this considerably less comfortable than facing them outright would've been.
*The fairy helper didn't have a story role after Floor 2.
*Bad Ending Two contradicted Senia's apparently unique ability to control Eternity, which had been established repeatedly throughout the game, and had been one of my favorite parts of the plot. (Extremely low curse resistance granting the power to safely channel dark magic was just a really fun idea to me.)
*The "true" ending was a sequel hook which undermined practically everything I'd been working for - and this was not a short game in terms of playtime, regardless of what Steam managed to record.
*The sequel apparently does exist, but it's switched both genres and mediums. I don't /want/ a phone game right now, so I probably won't play it.

48256672.review:
It didn't blow my mind, but it's addicting in its simplicity. I actually liked the action RPG aspect where your character automatically attacks when she comes into contact with an enemy so all you have to worry about is dodging, using special skills when you need them, and upgrading your skills and equipment. The mechanics aren't complicated or particularly deep but that's what makes it fun to breeze through. Bosses aren't a pushover but still easy enough to beat (except for the final boss if you're playing on hard, which could be a massive headache). You may have to do some grinding if you're looking for certain loot to upgrade equipment or need to level up your skills (especially important on hard difficulty). Story is okay, but the gameplay is really what kept me going. 

Overall I'm impressed that a free little JRPG managed to entertain me for a handful of hours, so if you want something short, fairly casual, and don't want to spend the money, it's a good game to keep you occupied.

48061939.review:
Mild spoilers ahead. If you haven't played the game yet or plan to, don't read this. I will also put spoiler boxes just in case.

When I first got this game, I'm not going to lie, it was just to pad my game count so I could get the 50 game badge. But I was bored, so I launched it up. My first impressions were kinda iffy, the story seemed cliche and the mechanics of a regular rpg weren't there(Like parties and such) But I kept playing. And eventually, I found myself sucked in. It's a short story, sure, about 3-4 hours long maybe, but man did it captivate me. I wanted to just keep playing. And the soundtrack, oh the soundtrack was phenomenal. It plays right when it needs to for maximum enjoyment, or sadness for that matter. The combat system was simple, but it was good. The difficulty was perfect. The replayablity seems to be good for another 2-3 ish hours.

For a free game, I'm very surprised at how well done this is. CG's and an expertly crafted soundtrack almost make it seem as if it were made by professionals. The translation is very well done, with minimal translation errors. It's almost like a visual novel, without being one. (Can I hope to get a VN for this too?) The characters are great, and you can feel the connection, however cliched between them. It's quite lovely. I reminds me of when I was young and the anime I used to watch, how hopeful they were. 

The only complaints I have about this game are probably the powercreep as soon as you enter a new dungeon, and maybe lack of materials, where I was only able to get the 3rd tier items for each weapon and armor without running through levels over and over(I've only played this game once so far). I also wish the game were longer, so we could see more relations built up(mainly between the fairy and Setnia, as the only interaction after the forest is mostly Setnia throwing her) but I can already see the amount of work put into this 3-4 hour game, so maybe I'm asking for too much. 

Now let's get into spoiler territory. About the ending.  [spoiler] The game builds you up for three hours to hit you with the first ending. You feels betrayed. You play for the second and third ending. The second is worse than the first by a long shot. The third gives you despair at first, then hope at the end. It's beautifully crafted, and bittersweet.  [/spoiler]

This game in absolutely a must play. It's at the low cost of free and only 3-4 hours long, not too big of a commitment. I'm buying the sequel immediately. I cannot get over how this game absolutely kicked my expectations to the ground and began beating them to a pulp.

Also, the sequel was released on mobile. It seems to be a standary grind-gacha game, so please be wary. I'm really hoping for an VN or a RPG port of the sequel story. Best of luck to the developers though!

10/10 - Masterpiece, and a must play.

This is a little RPG maker rpg. So my expectations were kind of minimum.

All games I rate start with a perfect score in each category. I reduce score based on imperfections that affect experience. Minor flaws that are over-lookable will have little impact on score. Overall Personal Score is calculated by the impact of each category on the first category. If Visuals are an 8 and Audio is a 6. the overall score so far is a 7.and the rest are calculated from there.

Visuals- It is PRG Maker, but damn the visuals were not subpar. Effects and environments look and feel great. Nothing extraordinary, but also nothing to complain about either. Im subtracting only because there is nothing truely gripping here. But still more than i expected from this type of game. 7/10

Audio- Man Holy Priest really needs to release the soundtrack. Suited the mood perfect. Other effects were nothing at all bad, but pleasant. solid 8/10

Presentation- Story telling was on point. He wrote a nice story, and told it well. Honestly for what this game is, This makes the game for me. 9/10

Gameplay- Simple, to the point, its satisfying, and it works perfectly. No imbalances here at all. Nothing above and beyond here though either. 6/10

Fun Factor- Directly to the point gameplay and narrative makes progressing this game entertaining. I wanted to continue my playthough. I didn't get bored. Honestly isnt that what we want from a game? Wasn't A top tier game. But above average for my expectations. 7/10

Overall Personal Score- 7.05/10 Its free, but it very well could at least be a 1 or 2 dollar game. I Enjoyed it mainly for the presentation, but the gameplay held it together. Nothing distracting you in this game. If you like little PRGs. Download and enjoy. I recommend this game to fans of the genre

First let's talk about things that I liked.
The equipment crafting mechanic is very interesting, the skills mechanic is very well executed and some of the enemies are pretty original.
But saddly though, the game isn't flawless. The locations are divided in stages that require you to kill all the enemies to progress like if it was some kind of beat-em up game, so for example we have trees or fences blocking our path that magically dissappear once we clean the stage… I don't like this kind of gameplay mechanics that make no sense plotwise/lorewise. Some of the locations are just simple straight corridors hunging in space – kinda lazy. Most of the game is spent on monster hunting, or to be more precise – grinding in order to get enough crafting materials to create required equipment to progress the game.

In general, it isn't a bad game, but the plot doesn't compensate the uninteresting hours of grinding, so after almost three hours of playing I am no longer interested enough to finish the game. I think if it were a bit better executed and not artificially extended, it would be much better.

47163957.review:
This is not a bad game. But it is also not a good game. (At least not as good as the overall reviews suggest..)
It's nice that it is free. If it wasn't, I wouldn't want to pay much for it.
You can play through the whole thing 100% in 5 or 6 hours. Maybe even less. That is ok.

Pretty much all of the game is running around, "attacking" monsters (by running into them), finding some switches and occasional dialogue (or monologue).

Since there are many monsters to fight, I like that the game has its own battle system and not the default one from the RPG Maker. The game would have been horribly tedious to play. All you have to do is run into the monster to attack it. Most monsters need 1-3 hits. Sadly that means the battles are pretty easy and there's no challenge at all. No tactic when to use skills or when to retreat. Boss battles are mostly the same except they have more HP and stronger attacks which you should dodge.
Another thing I liked however: If you run out of HP (you don't die), you simply start from the last waypoint keeping the EXP so if you really need to level up you don't have to start over since your last save.

The story is pretty basic. The idea isn't bad but I think it could have been much more. You barely get to know the characters which is sad because all the way through the game and even in the endings I didn't really care about them. Nothing really unexpected happens. Most of the story is told in flashbacks and not happening "now". That is not bad, but it doesn't help. At some point I nearly wanted to skip through the scenes because there wasn't really new information, just another scene displaying the already pretty clear relationship between the two main characters.

Since it's free I would have liked to give a neutral rating, not a bad one. Try it if you like the RPG Maker style but don't expect much. The game is nice for a day when you're lying in bed with a cold and can't do much but don't want to sleep all day... :)

45652804.review:
Greetings everyone, 
Today I will be reviewing the multi-award winning game ‘Barbie and Her Sisters: Puppy Rescue’, and why I personally believe that everybody should get the chance to play this incredible masterpiece.

The game tells an eloquent tale about Barbie beginning off her adventure by leaving her previous life of crime, prostitution and drug abuse as she tries to redeem herself by capturing puppies and selling them to an illegal underground dog fighting ring run by the a Japanese gang who call themselves the Sewer Rats. The Sewer Rats are infamous for beating and sexually assaulting the transsexual people(s) of Willows, Wisconsin; they have an interesting way of humiliating their victims; this is accomplished by forcing as many sewer pickles up the victim’s anal cavity. 

Barbie’s three sisters; Skipper, Stacey and Chelsea help her out this magical journey as they all bring a unique skill set to the table, Stacy for instance comes from Japanese heritage and is very good at kidnaping the dogs and cooking one or two of them up if your hunger meter gets too low. Chelsea comes from African heritage therefore she makes a very good distraction when the police inevitably come after you. And Skipper, who has one of the most interesting skill sets, is a Jew so she is extremely good with finance and handling the money you get from selling the dogs.

The story is set in Barbie’s crime-riddled home town Willows, Wisconsin; which is very similar to Detroit, USA. Willows, Wisconsin is a city which is populated mostly by African American people, and packed full of crime. On just about every street corner you come across you will find at least one meth addicted homeless hooker. This adds a dark tone to the game which completely sucks you into the story line leaving you wanting to play more.

All in all ‘Barbie and Her Sisters: Puppy Rescue’ has been an absolutely amazing play for me because it doesn’t hesitate to touch on dark tones such as prostitution and drug abuse. And hopefully one day when people recognize how great of a game this really is, it will reach an E-Sport level. But in my honest opinion my only ‘huge’ problem with the game is not playing it sooner, and I hope that all the people that are smart enough to pick up the game have their own extraordinary and eye opening experiences.

Thank you all for taking the time to read this and I hope everyone has a great day, also remember my dudes, stay positive aha that’s crazy.

This was a very pleasantly casual experience, which is sounds like was the developer's intent. I'd say it was a great success on that account. It's not a sprawling AAA epic, so just don't go in expecting one, and you'll be fine. The perfect short little casual aRPG that's lovely to play when you just want to relax for a bit and have something sweet.

Now here's a room with an elephant: so let's discuss this first.
This is a RPGMaker game, complete with assets from the original.
There is some nice new anime artwork however and the obligatory intro story.

And yet, and yet.

It sidesteps the tedium of combat by allowing the user to remain on-map and run-through an opponent: the result being like a flip of a coin whereby you either win the day or take a bloody nose.

So it keeps the action going over some nicely-done maps across a nicely-paced  story.

It is brimful of love and care and despite the limitations of the engine it really is one to recommend. RPGMaker has many detractors, so I am proud to stand alongside those games that push the genre.

42359089.review:
Oh my goodness, what a rush!

[h1]AwesomeSauce[/h1]

[list]
[*]Beautiful story of sisterly bonds.
[*]Endearing female protagonist that bends the usual tropes (though doesn't completely break them).
[*]Fantastic music that loops a bit too often but didn't seem overly-repetitive to me.  Every unique area has a distinct and mostly-memorable theme.
[*]Three* possible diverse endings and you don't have to replay too much to get them all!
[*]Interesting real-time action-based 2D combat on both the X and Y axis.
[*]Challenging boss fights with variable difficulty (easy, normal, and hard modes).
[*]Difficulty does NOT affect the endings (yay!) so you can do easy mode for a nice relaxing stress-free story run.
[/list]

[h1]GreasyOil[/h1]

[list]
[*]Hard Bosses can really be difficult due to all the crap on screen at once.  Final boss is near-impossible to beat on Hard Mode without perfect precision.  Luckily this is mitigated by choosing an easier difficulty WITHOUT any ending penalty for doing so.
[*]Certain enemies present zero challenge, especially the large optional "elite" bosses that are supposed to be tougher but stand there doing absolutely nothing.  LAME!  They drop legendary crafting materials so at least there's a reason to bother.
[*]Critical Books grinding is obscenely bad; purely dependant on RNG drops in one specific area you have to run often 10+ times while needing 4 pages per book with barely a single page per run if you're really unlucky with RNG.
[*]You get overloaded with so many useless/unused crafting materials, equipment, and items that they clutter your inventory.  I can understand there wouldn't really be a need for a 'shop' system in a Tower of Evil, but why can't we at least drop our unwanted non-key items?
[*]The last sword item (Trial) is only the 2nd-best sword in the game, but has a higher 'attack' stat than the best sword in the game and thus is a newbie trap.
[*]Despite being 2nd-best, the last area's sword and armor are still required for the 'legendary' collection reward.
[*]If you don't check a guide, it is quite possible to permanently miss crucial stat-boosting items and be unable to equip/use the best-in-slot gear for the final boss fight.
[/list]

*There's additional goodies if you install the Emperium Mod (check Guides under Community Hub for this game).

Despite the faults, the game is worth playing for the story alone.
Do yourself a favor and skip the grind by doing all bosses on 'easy' mode while skipping the collection and other stuff.  Easy mode is easy enough that they aren't required at all and you can probably skip most equipment upgrades until the final area.

I've got over 11 hours in this game and at least ~3 hours of that was spent grinding for those damn 'critical buff' books in the astral zones.

After playing this game for a little while, like at least 1-2 minutes or something? I can tell you that this game is truly amazing and worth a play through. Even after now 5 years its still a great game.

The game has some of the best music I've heard in a JRPG/ARPG. The boss fights are unique and the bosses sprites are pretty good too. The fighting is simple but not too easy and not too hard depending how you play through this game. (If you grind the game is easy, if you just go through without grinding the game is moderately hard)

Not to mention the story and characters. My god every time I play through this game there is still someone cutting onions next to me for some reason. Honestly, I did start to tear up and I did shed a couple tears due to what happens. This game plays with your emotions very well.

With my latest play through I used a mod called "Emperium" which fixes a lot of bugs, translations, sprites and most important adds a new ending. Though I would recommend going through all the endings I can saying that ending 4 from this mod is truly what most us wanted and was a great new ending to the game. No matter if it is your first time through or maybe looking to replay it I would highly recommend this mod as it really adds to the game without completely redoing it and losing the original game.

Though this game is pretty popular I do wish it received even more love than it already has gotten. Without a doubt a great game.

Note: You can find this mod on the Steam community forums for this game, its made by HenWRYY.

41517635.review:
My overall score for this game: B-

This game is not flawless, but it was enjoyable. It was a labor of love and was released for free, and that does influence my score. I would expect more polish from a commercial effort that I paid for.

The plot was intriguing, even if parts of it seemed a bit stereotypical for it's JRPG/anime genre. I'm left wondering about the world as a whole, beyond the Tower of Eternity, and how Senia and Magaleta lived before the game began. The art and music were great. I wasn't a fan of all the enemy sprites, but overall, it was a good looking "16-bit" game.

I do wish the English translation had been edited to sound a little more natural, and I found all three endings a little bit frustrating, but if there's a sequel, I'd be interested in knowing where the story heads after this.  In such a sequel, I'd like to see outside of the Tower of Eternity, with the Tower being the final area (probably). If you like JRPGs or RPGMaker games, it's worth a try.

40592262.review:
Eternal Senia is a pretty good game, that shows what possibilities RPG Maker has to offer.

The fighting-system is different and clearly lifts this game out from the crowd of RPG Maker games, that only uses the from the RPG Maker supplied engine.
Using a crafting system to upgrade your equipment, instead of buying or finding new equipment, is also a good and different idea to make this game more unique.
Sometimes I missed the possibility to use potions, to regenerate HP and MP, but that was only in the fights with a boss the case, and for that reason quite bearable.

The story and proceding within the same was exceedingly interesting.
The only thing that made me a bit sad was the fact, that there is no real "happy end".
Three different endings, but none of them was really a "happy end".
Well, at least it felt like that to me.

Otherwise was Eternal Senia a game, that I would always like to play again.
In this sense I clearly can recommend this game.
And this game is for free!
So what can you do wrong?

Eternal Senia is NOT a bad game (for being a free one at least). However, I'm giving it a negative review based int he fact that it does not lives uop to the spectations that such a high ranking in steam generates. Many of the deficiencies left me without the sensation of achieving something after finishing the game or even the desire to replay the game to have all the ending.

Story 3/10:
While most praise its plot, it was a little too dramatic to my liking. The "gotta save my sister" tale just told me it was just another cliche rpg story which made it hard for me to get into it or sympathize with any of the caracters. While not being too boring, it just didn't  made me want to play more to know more about the plot. All of that made me not even sorrow at the tragic end.

Music 7/10:
It was most certainly the redeeming feature of this game. While the songs won't be something I download to listen over and over again. It set the atmosphere just right and wasn't distracting at all. 

Gameplay 4/10:
I'm a bit salty about this one. It could have been so much better. The mages and bosses fight were so good, you had to position yourself well and know when to attack it made those fights really entertaining. The minibosses and most melee monsters, however,  just stood there waiting for you to kill them. That was so boring, it didn't feel like a fight at all. Moreover the decision of the team to not have an attack botton made the controlers a lot worse than they could have been. Your character sometimes attacked automatically a nearby enemy when alll you were trying to do was dodge. Is was a real mess. What's more, the leveling balance was really off, you could destroy all the bosses except the last one just by sheer force because there is just no balance in that sistem,

Overall 5/10:
In conlusion, while it is certainly not a masterpiece, as its ranking will have you believe, it is worth a go if you want interesting boss fights and a free steam game.

40431477.review:
The best part, for me, is that there are only four skills in this game. That allows me to put each skill onto a shoulder button on my PS3 controller, and not have any issues. All told, you just need four movement keys and six other buttons to do anything you want in this game. It's glorious. The music is nice for a free game, and the amount of content is passable. Play this without expecting a super amazing game, and you'll be pleasantly surprised with it. Play it while comparing it to RPG Maker behemoths like Undertale or Yume Nikki, and you'll be disappointed.

TL;DR: Fun game, short, nice music. Play if want small nice game.

I totally respect the negative reviews but... what the heck? 

The author says it all: this game is meant to be relaxing, pleasant, enjoyable, yet challenging at the right times. Not overwhealming, nor stressing or anything like hardcore gameplay. 

If you're looking for complex gameplays and something difficult like hell even for a casual play, there's a handful of bullet hell options at the store, you might try rogue-like s**t plenty of monsters. That's all. For the ones coming from working and spending their time while watching Netflix and making backup like me, go on, it might be your game.

In the other hand, what you have is a well developed RPG Maker piece of art with simple but brainfucking puzzles (if you're going all by yourself good luck finding all chests, not that easy really if you're a perfeccionist motherf**k*r like me). A beautiful plot for anyone: those sinking in nostalgia for Ragnarök Online and those who never touched that addictive Gravity hell of a MMORPG (you know now which one I am). 

I have no regrets and well, even you find it predictable to go through the "good" ending like me, it still have some replay value. In the worst case you spend 156 MB in your hard disk, so...

38894499.review: This game is a gem of an RPG Maker project. The combat is simple yet fun, the story is good enough to justify the gameplay, and skill and item progression is engaging. Beyond some minor grammar issues with the localization, the translation from the original Chinese is rather good (especially considering the records of similar localizations). A playthrough will likely take between 4-6 hours and the grind, as present in most all JRPGs, is never boring. The crafting/upgrade system encourages you to backtrack a little, but it is never too demanding or overbearing. If you need any final selling points on this game, it's free. That's right free. And has as much (if not more) polish than many paid RPG Maker games on Steam currently. So, yeah, download this game and support the creator. This was definitely a passion project for Holy Priest and it shines through in his game.

now i can say with confidence that this is the first game to ever make me cry, and ive been playing games since i was four years old or so. the story is a bit slow at the start and english translations are rarely perfect, but after a while it just explodes in your face like "SURPRISE BITCH GIMME YO TEARS". i genuinely shed tears after the second and third endings(there are three in total) and the third one especially got to me, although the second one was really shocking as well. regardless of which one you end up with(i recommend trying to get all three though), all the endings were very well delivered. whoever made this game should be very proud of themselves for creating a relaxing game that is at the same time far from relaxing lol

38390906.review:
The appeal in the game to me, suprisingly, is in the gameplay. I wasn't really captured by the story, as sweet as it was,so much as the drive to upgrade all the items, do the small mini quests, and buff my character - just keep fighting. As widespread as the rpgmaker style game is, it's not often where combat becomes such a large part, and it was done fairly well.

Granted, if you hope to find all the chests, have the materials to make the best weapons, or even find a certain route that unlocks 2/3 of the endings, you may want to use a guide. But overall, the difficulty is very flexible where it counts. There might be a couple puzzles to stump you. Entering actual boss fights on Easy mode feels like absolutely cheesing it, honestly. But the store page said this game was meant to be a kind of adventure game that can be played by [i]anyone[/i], so I'm thinking Easy is for people who would just like a more immersive visual novel.

Like I said, I didn't find the story all that compelling. A quest to find a lost loved one, though I'll hand it to the writer that none of the three endings are exactly happy, which does add a nice bittersweet taste to the game. It was nothing to write home about, but a fun time.

38327052.review:
This is a fun free RPG with real-time combat. 

The difficulty level is geared towards casual gamers; save points are plentiful and your health regenerates over time. There are a few tougher boss battles but they can be played on an easier difficulty level if you wish (I played on the Normal difficulty without problems).

There is also a crafting system which is simple but effective. There are a few mini-games; for example one is a spoof of Pac-Man. There are also some very easy puzzles to add variety to the combat.

Graphics are not AAA quality; this an indie game made using RPG Maker. I know a lot of people immediately dismiss RPG Maker games (because, let's face it, so many of them are bad). But in this case it's probably the best, most innovative use of RPG Maker I've seen, and the graphics are more than suitable for what the developer is trying to accomplish.

The game is mostly linear so it's basically impossible to get lost. 

The plot is one of the game's strongest points. At first it seems to be a pretty straightforward quest in which a young girl (Senia) is looking for her missing sister. But as more of the plot is unveiled through short cutscenes and flashbacks things get a lot more sinister. Eventually you start to question the very basis of what you thought was your quest. At the very end the plotline branches (with savepoints nearby being nice enough to warn you!) and there are three possible endings. It took me about six hours to complete every optional quest and get all three endings. 

Unfortunately English is not the author's main language. So expect some spelling and grammar issues with the translation. 

For some reason the game starts out in windowed mode. After looking in the Settings screen I saw that pressing F5 and F6 can adjust the screen. I played in full screen mode and did have a few brief instances of choppy frame rates, but overall the game ran well on Windows 7 64 bit and I encountered no bugs.

The soundtrack consists of numerous catchy tunes.

I enjoyed Eternal Senia. If you're not a stickler for graphics and you like ARPGs with a strong emphasis on story and gameplay it's well worth checking out!

37925058.review:
Story:

We play as Senia, a young girl who’s climbing the Tower of Eternity to find her sister. That the best short summary I can give without going into spoilers.

Lets get the bad out of the way, I think it needs a better translator. What story that was translated is good and I’ll be saying good things later, but there some little bits here and there that bother. I shouldn't care that Senia calls Magaleta sis but sometimes it just doesn’t sound right when I’m reading it. And second is the fairy. Now there isn’t anything  wrong with the character itself but outside of gameplay, she barely does anything to the story and I forgot she was around.

Now for the good. While we don’t know the full relationship between the two leads, we do get flashbacks that explore how they meet and why they care so much about each other. I was getting pretty invested in by the end of the story.

Gameplay:

The game is an action RPG with a very simple battle system where you just have touch an enemy to kill them. you can get four moves to help with combat and two can be used to find secret with one being a dash and the other being a range attack and the other two are useful attacks that hit lots of enemies.

Now while these are fun to use, the enemies are ridiculously easy to beat and you might not get a dent when you fight them, which is a shame since some of the enemies are pretty fun to fight like the magic users and the ones that charge at you. I think this clip from SAO abridged some up the combat perfectly

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hH5qZgjDBSY

But the worst fights are the king fights. There’s a side quest where to get the best equipment in a level and to get the gems for the most powerful stuff, you have to kill one of the four kings in a level which look like bigger enemies. I thought these  were going to be harder fights with regular enemies but they turned out to be literal punching bags. All you have to do is use you rush attack until you’re out of MP and wait till you have enough to hit them again. Sure you can die if you too careless of hitting them with your face but the penalty for death so just to go back to the last save point try again once you realize the boring tactic of waiting works on all of them.

Now you might be think that the combat is a boring slog but I think its more underwhelming than anything. But I do one subject of praise are the boss fights. These are some hectic battles where they will just shot different attack or spawn enemies to deal with and these were the funnest parts of the game. The moment I fought the King Slime I saw how good this combat can be and stuck around not just to see what happens next in the story but to see what’s the next big fight.

Presentation:

Not much to say as most of the art since most of them are just RPG Maker default sprites but the sprites for Senia and Magaleta look cute. And the original artwork looks pretty good and really give a emotional punch. And  while I don’t know if all the music was from free sources, I thought it was used  pretty well.

Verdict:

While the gameplay could be a bit boring at times, the story and boss fights kept me interested.

7/10

37667323.review:
Oh my gosh, this game was AMAZING! The dev worked hard to make this game both smooth in gameplay yet challenging, and I was not disappointed. It doesn't take extremely long to play, around 5 or 6 hours, but those are 5 or 6 hours you wil not regret.
One of the big things that stood out to me was the regular enemy battle style. I like not having to enter sepereate battle scenes every time I run into an enemy but just running into them until they die (It's more satisfying than it sounds). Some enemies are fairly static, but others have special abilities or moves that require you to strategize as well. Despite not having a full-on RPG-style battle mode, armor and weapons are still important, and I enjoyed trying to gather enough materials to collect all of them. I think having a hierarchy of making one piece of equipment require the next one down allowed for actual progress in the game as opposed to just getting the highest-ranked equipment from the start, which is a smart move. 
The boss battles were challenging, too, and are different than regular enemy encounters. They do have a battle mode where you are trapped in one area, and they are the most challenging parts of the game. This game also had multiple endings, which I always like in a game. Each game ending was special, and in one of them you get an extra boss! All I can say is that I died a few times trying to defeat her. The rest is spoilers. ;)
The plot was not shabby, either. It starts out giving you a classic plot line, but more is revealed as the game goes on, which leads to interesting plot twists that create a unique story from the lost-person-must-save-them archetype. The plot also leaves the endings alone, in the sense that there isn't a bias over which choices you should make at the end. Either choice is acceptable, but they lead to completely different endings, as opposed to them not mattering. It's relieving after playing some games where the choices lead to generally the same ending.
I HIGHLY recommend this game to the casual gamer or the general RPG fan. Someone looking for hardcore Final Fantasy- style gameplay will not get that here, although those people may still enjoy the game. This is a beautifully well-rounded game that, in my opinion, has an almost perfect balance of everything. It's amazing that it's free, so give it a try.

Eternal Senia is actually my favorite game that I've ever played on Steam.

It is as well-made and memorable as any legendary RPG from the Super Nintendo era. Playing the game literally made me feel 15 years younger. Combat is fun and balanced, there's plenty to obsess over for completionists, and the bosses have a hard mode for people who want a challenge. The characters and storyline were great and extremely memorable. The developer believes games should be a fun experience, and his work reflects that stance.

There are three endings; the first ending is the "bad" one, but I actually like it better than the other two endings, which feel tragic to me in different ways. There were loose ends and unutilized dialogue, but these seem to be intentional, and are used as a sequel hook in one of the endings. "Eternal Senia: Hydrangea After the Rain" is now in development for Android.

36458457.review:
A fun, unassuming game, Eternal Senia impressed me more than I thought it would.

*Before I talk about anything, I want to mention that the soundtrack is phenomenal.  It really makes you realize how important music can be to the overall experience.*

The game and story are both short and sweet.  The story itself hits a soft spot for me, so I'm probably biased, but all things considered it's not especially unique or noteworthy on it's own.  It's good, but not unique, let's say.  

Likewise, the base combat is also incredibly simple; run into enemies to deal damage.  Unfortunately, this means that you're spending a lot of time doing essentially very little, just moving from boss fight to boss fight.  The boss fights are much more spectacular, and legitimately challenging, considering how the rest of the game plays, but are also where some of the problems with the combat design present themselves.

Things like hit stun, lingering hitboxes, and occassionally hard to read attacks can make some of the fights frustrating, especially on hard mode.  The boss fights frequently morph into a psuedo bullet hell style of game, but the game doesn't necessarily handle well enough to prevent you from dying to things in ways that don't feel particularly fair.

However, all that being said, I do think that Eternal Senia was a lot of fun, and I definitely enjoyed the experience.  For the low, low price of free, it's a hard deal to beat.

36177142.review:
A fantastic game with extremely unique gameplay and a lovingly crafted story with various endings. It feels heavily inspired by final fantasy but it's anything but. It's truly worth your time. And best of all, it's free. By all means try this game. Not all endings are created equil, but this one was the love child born from the best of every RPG giant I can think of.  

The game revolves around a girl trying to find her older sister in a mysterious tower full of monsters and puzzles. She meets many interesting characters, villains, friends and sceneries on the way. Many are call backs to her past, others are just really cool things to look at. The enemies are all unique-ish and are fun to deal with. The game is friendly for all people whether you are good OR bad at video games, so please sit down for a while and enjoy this extremely well made game that was painstakingly made by a guy who just wanted to share his vision with you.

36061855.review:
Qué decir, sinceramente me lleve una de las [b] mejores sorpresas [/b] sobre este juego, no esperaba demasiado de un Free To Play pero resultó ser una pequeña joyita; seré breve ya que es un juego simple pero bien hecho:
Eternal Senia es un RPG maker con una estica caracteristica del género pero con un sistema de combate un poco distinta a la mayoría, en lugar de entrar en una larga y aburrida batalla contra un grupo de mounstros por turnos hay un combate en tiempo real, te acercas, atacas y recibes daños dependiendo de la fuerza del enemigo, si es extremadamente simple pero es entretenido; tambien hay recetas para armas o armaduras que mejoran tus estadisticas, no hay elecciónes de tipo "este da más ataque pero menos habilidad" solo hay mejoras y esto en lo personal lo agradesco ya que no me gusta la idea de pasar horas en una tienda solo para decidir cual arma me conviene más y volver a este proceso cada vez que desbloqueo algo.
[b] Los jefes !son lo mejor que he visto en el género¡ [/b] ya que el combate es en tiempo real, los jefes se convierten en una serie de patrones y esbirros a esquivar para decidir el momento idoneo para atacar; tambien hay habilidades que vas a querer spamear aunque recibas daño si las tienes a un nivel alto, cabe destacar que noo hay objetos curativos, no hay habilidades de curacion, hay regeneracion natural pero creeme que no va a ser muy facil esquivar a un jefe durante 10 min; de esta forma se compensan las habilidades que son verdaderamente destructivas
Por ultimo la historia, no quiero spoilear nada porque el juego es muy [i] muy [/i] corto (calculo no más 7 horas al 100%) pero voy a decir que es una historia triste y que !tiene 3 finales! la verdad no me lo esperaba en lo absoluto y aunque solo consegui un final el mismo juego te da la pista de como conseguir los demas, otra cosa que tambien agradesco, el no tener que estar en un eclispe, tras haber matado a 4 enemigos distintos en un orden determinado solo para abrir una puerta que a saber tu donde está y conseguir un final diferente; como extra a todo esto tenemos la banda sonora, no es la mejor que haya escuchado pero sin duda me gusta mucho
En conclusión: pasa perfectamente como juego de pago, si te gustan los RPG´s, por favor juega Eternal Senia, no te va a quitar mucho tiempo y no te vas a arrepentir.

35771001.review:
This game deserves much more recognition. Emphasis and the MUCH. 
GREAT character development, wide variety of monsters and monster art, GREAT artwork, AWESOME storyline, AMAZING soundtrack, and a simple yet VERY CLEAN combat and upragding/crafting system. The game flows well enough to the point where you're actually trying to find flaws with it as someone would a $60 game. The only couple falws I'd complain about are the run-into-enemy combat, and mini bosses (that drop upgrade shards). Running into the enemy is a great idea for a simple pixel-game but debris/destrucible objects should be included. There were times I didn't know when to simply run into something, or smash the spacebar. Mini bosses should also be mobile within their area, and given an attack pattern. Same as their smaller versions would be fine but going the extra mile to give them a totally different arsenal would be the cherry on top. You could kill it by simply using skills, and waiting for your mana to refresh without taking damage. THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPH IS MY EMOTIONAL ATTACHMENT TOWARDS THIS GAME AND NOT EXACTLY PART OF THE REVIEW FOR THIS GAME.

I say all this in retrospect to the fact that THIS GAME IS FREE. Not the buggy/glitchy, hardly-any-content kind of free game, but the kind of free game that makes you want to personally thank the developer(s) for pouring their heart and soul into such a masterpiece and sharing it with the rest of us. All this becomes apparent as you delve into the game with the developer(s) as you explore the bonus area they leave behind for players that finish the game. It's obvious that a lot of passion went into this game and that the developer(s) loves what they do. It's games like these that rekindle my love for gaming and drive my appreciation for it. Games like LoL, R6S, and even GW2 have become my go-to games that have left me feeling stressed, and empty afterwards. It's games like these that adhere to the very aspect of gaming; filling their players with joy, tension, sadness, guilt, sympathy, curiosity, and a sense of purpose.

35748204.review:
I am absolutely blown away by this game. The art is wonderful, the combat might be simple, but it's effective. The game aims to tell a story in a relaxing but fun manner and it achieves its goals to the perfect standard. There seems to be three ways you can play. Easy, Regular and Hard. I played every single boss on Hard, and the only difficulty I had was on the 3rd boss.

For a free game, I can't complain about anything. Naturally I believe assets were used from something else possibly, but the developer did the best with what they had, and gave us a masterpiece. Sure, it's not a triple A game or anything, but for 3-5 hours of play-time and to get that play-time for free? I'd say give it a shot.

If this had cost money, I would not have been disappointed either.

Fantastic game.

Gameplay: Simple yet fun.

Music: Very enjoyable.

Visuals: Also mostly simple, but effective. The stills and "cutscenes" (if you want to call them that) as well as the character portraits are all very nice.

Story: This is where this game really shines. Relatively short, but very impactful. A lot of heart put into it, which can be said with the rest of the game as well. Would recommend the game on this alone.

My only real criticism is that some things aren't translated very well into English. You get some grammatical errors and what not because of it, but this doesn't detract from the story at all. You can still tell what is being said. This game is free, but I would have paid for it if that was the only option. If there is a sequel, I'll pay for that too!

35346206.review:
So, I finally decided to spend my whole Saturday playing the game after already having it in my library for a while now, and boy I have to say this game is AMAZNG. I'll make bullet points to make it easy to read.
- Storyline: I won't spoil anything, but I guarantee you'll enjoy the whole storyline, it was simple, wasn't confusing and gave me quite a lot of emotions.
- Combat: Very simple, it was meant to be for all gamers, bad and good ones, really easy to pick up.
- Music: Every soundtrack was different, and different in a good way, some were calming and nice, some were fit for the scene, overall really good.
- Art: very impressed by the art work as well as graphics. Art work was cute, adorable. Graphics was good, nostalgic to those old ARPGs, I actually appreciate that since I've only been playing AAA games lately, this was such a good change.
  Overall, I really love the game, it gave me the "feels", definitely would cry again??? haha
If there was a sequel, I would want it to be a little longer, with a bit more complexity, and I WOULD pay for the sequel.

Recommended. Give it try, folks!

Yo, so like, this game is like real good. I was pleasantly surprised when I began playing; I just couldn’t stop. For a 4-6 hour adventure, it is truly addicting and captivating. The music is pleasant, the story easily pulls a few heartstrings, and the combat is surprisingly fun for being so simple. I enjoyed the progression system of abilities and equipment, albeit it could be a bit grindy for equipment, but it’s not nearly as bad as you’d think. The fact that the game is so short means that the grindy bits don’t get annoying until the very end, if they get annoying at all. 
The biggest downside to the game is that the english translations are a bit rough in some areas. While the game is understandable, sometimes the English is the equivalent of a bad Manga Scanlation. It can be a bit annoying at times, but as mentioned before: The game is still understandable. Personally, it didn’t bother me all that much, but it was noticeable.
Overall the game is really good. I didn’t expect much from a free steam RPG, but Holy God was I impressed. The people who made this game put a lot of love into it. I look forward to the sequel.

Eternal Senia es un ARPG hecho en RPGMaker hecho por un chino, en el que su primer juego desarrollado. segun él, queria hacer algo atractivo y dinanimo utilizando las falencias de la herramienta que utiliza. 

El juego tiene una historia lineal, mientras transcurre se va liberando y entrelazando el pasado de la protagonista llamada Senia. Tiene una visual un poco carecida, pero bien utilizada. La musica ambiental muy buena, tiene los tonos adecuados a los sucesos que ocurren en ese momento. Se agradece que tenga un modo de crafting para desarrollar tus propias armas, pero cuidado, porque a veces necesitas materiales que estan en otro mundo y no podras regresar (recomiendo leer guias para que puedas armarte muy bien y no se te complique el juego mas adelante). El diseño de personajes es muy colorido como sus etapas, puedes llegar a encariñarte con ellos facilmente.

Lo recomiendo mucho por su historia, su forma de juego muy simple pero adictivo y por su musica. Tambien decir que el juego posee 3 finales distintos, ya que en la primera pasada se te hara un juego con un tiempo mediano, pero luego vez que no es tan asi, ya que su duracion es adecuada. 

Pd: Sacaron una secuela, pero es para celular/movil... bueh

34234201.review:
Just finished beating Eternal Senia after a long hiatus and I enjoyed my experience.  If you enjoyed the Ys I & II Chronicles (the ones with the bump system), then you'll enjoy this game as well, despite four-directional movement.  This means that whenever you bump into an enemy, you take damage as well, but since you regenerate health over time, having good armor and utilizing your combat techniques will help you last longer.

Speaking of combat techniques, they actually provide puzzle-solving opportunities.  The first one you get allows you to dash over gaps as well as providing a short burst of speed (allowing you to use as a dodge).  The third one is much more obvious, as you throw a fairy that can activate switches at a distance.

The boss battles of this game are pretty interesting.  I think that, because this game was made with some form of RPG Maker, they're sprites that are supposed to be in a turn-based combat system, because they're immobile.  Despite this, area attacks, barriers, and summoned mobs help spice up boss fights.  Not only that, before each boss fight, you have the option of selecting the difficulty.

This game is divided into a tutorial area and three major areas, each providing you with upgrade materials for different tiers of gear and stat upgrades.  Just before each area boss, there are three NPCs that reward you with items for achievements such as killing a certain number of monsters, finding all of the chests, and creating the area's legendary equipment.

Last but not least, this game has three endings.

The story is a sad one about kinship, the loss of siblings, and of sacrificing one's humanity to get their ultimate wishes granted.

Like the earliest Ys games, this game takes from 3-6 hours to complete, depending on how much of a completionist you are.  I was actually surprised that I played from start to finish in one sitting.  I give this game a thumbs up.

34219528.review: This is a free-to-play JRPG with *some* basic RPG elements, however this game is not fleshed out at all. It's a neat little demo to mess around with some afternoon when you're bored. The English translation is atrocious (no subject-verb agreement) and several of the sentences are pretty awkward ("I will prioritize on my sister"...huh?). The game starts out just dropping you in the middle of the story without much context, and tries to develop the plot as-you-go via flashbacks. I gave it a good hour or so, and still have just a vague understanding of what was going on. The controls are very easy, and the monsters are easy to beat. Essentially, you don't press any keys to trigger an attack, but rather you just run your charater into them and she will automatically swing her sword at them. After 2-3 hits tops, the monster is killed and you go on your merry way. I could see this being a great game if it was developed more, but it just really bugged me that the storyline wasn't fleshed out and my character seemed to just be fighting monsters for fighting's sake.

33753557.review:
Don't expect to spend longer than four or five hours on this, even if some of that time is devoted to grinding. The controller mapping is in serious need of change. I used an Xbox controller for windows and was confused the whole time as to why certain decisions were made. For instance, there are four special moves in the game, yet none of those were mapped to the main A, B, X and Y buttons. Two were mapped to the Start and Back buttons, and two weren't mapped to any button on the controller at all, which made for awkward combat encounters at some stages.

Having said that, Eternal Senia is an endearing little game about the love between two sisters, a relationship not often explored in video games. There were emotional moments and three considerably different endings, a feat many AAA games can't even achieve. Considering the game is free, it's certainly worthwhile for a short weekend diversion.

If you're looking for something to while away an hour or two feel free to check it out, but I think I would rather have spent the time reading.

33379175.review:
So I was browsing Ragnarok-related games and came across this one. At first, i thoght it would be simple and light in story, but I was wrong! The story turned out to be good and gave me so much feels!

To make the review simple and easy to understand, I shall use a few categories:

Gameplay : 9/10
Combat is simple and easy to learn, with sufficient guides and a unique combat system so that even people who are not used to playing games can still complete the dungeons. 
Difficulty for boss can be set to either easy for those having troubles beating it, or hard for those seeking more challenge.
Equipment crafting is simple, and the extra stage in each dungeon for farming materials helps a lot in crafting.

Story : 9.5/10
The story starts out simple, with our protagonist Senia looking for her missing sister. She then ventures into the tower of eternity, hoping to find her sister there. The story then flows along and we see more about their pasts, which provides more background for us to emphatise with the character.

BGM : 9/10
The music is well put, and fits well with the scene/situation.

SFX : 9/10
the sound effects are clean and appropriately used.

Overall : 9.5/10
I enjoyed playing it, and the only thing I am not satisfied with is how short it was (I have 100% completion in 5 or 6 hours). definitely recommending this game and looking forward to its second installment!

I don't know what to say without mentioning something which is already said. 
So I think I'm gonna tell you my expectations and experiences about the game.

After reading all the praise for Eternal Senia for its storytelling, I decided to play it since I was bored at that time. Easy gameplay, just "died" two times in a fight because I didn't pay attention to my health bar, but if you improve your skills and equipment, it won't take too much effort to beat this game. Therefore it is really relaxing, but also entertaining. I like the artstyle for Senia and Magaleta and I really wish that I could see more "cutscenes". 

So I expected a good, fun game to play. However, after finishing the first boss and seeing more and more of Senias background story, I wanted to keep on playing it. Not merely because I wanted to level up, but to experience the story and see how it will end. Will Senia be able to find her sister Magaleta and bring her back home? Or will she forever stay in the Tower of Eternity? And the main reason, why I just have to complete it, is, that I can feel for the characters, thanks to the background stories of Senia and Magaleta. 
Eternal Senia is heartwarming and yet sad, with (at least for me 'cause I'm dumb) one unexpected plot twist at the very end. It is a story about the love of two sisters, about loss, and about maturing and resolve. 
So yeah, I was kinda overwhelmed to get such a beautiful game experience from a FREE game. I recommend it and if there would be a sequel, I would gladly play it^^

32608256.review:
Eternal Senia is a free RPG Maker game that plays more like a classic Legend of Zelda game than a traditional turn-based RPG. You play as Senia - a young adventurer looking for her adoptive sister Magaleta who went missing in the Tower of Eternity. The story and character motivations are told largely through flashbacks and at the end you have a full picture of why our two main characters do what they do - though it is largely a simple story, it is well-executed and easily understood even despite some translation hiccups from the developer's native Mandarin.

The meat of the gameplay is interesting and keeps the player engaged throughout the duration of the story - adding both new skills and new craftable equipment (really, direct upgrades to the player's current gear) as the plot warrants. It is a short game - about three to four hours of dedicated gameplay would be enough to complete and unlock the game's three endings.

For those looking for a good RPG Maker game or a serviceable Legend of Zelda top-down adventure, I would highly recommend Eternal Senia. To everyone else, give it a shot or at least add it to your library - it's free!

A somewhat interesting story at the begining slowly devolves as the game play gets repetitive and puzzles are so simple that they barely held my atention. I stuck through all the way till the end and chose 2 endings of what could have been 3 if I had done my saving a little better. Both endings I got to left a sour taste in my mouth because both were not what I wanted. That was unexpected and was one good thing about the game. Overall because it is a free game and not made by a big developer it was a great feat in making a 4 hour game, but with the repetitive game play and the mandatory grinding sessions that were made even more insulting by the game having a grinding realm it was not welly thought out and for me earns this indie title a 4/10 being slightly below average at best. If you have nothing else to do that might garner this game a play, but there are plenty of other more interesting games out there that a free and much better than this.

Also the addition of a facebook page place that has now been taken down to give you minor rewards for checking the page out I felt was very out of place and should not have been put in the game. 

If anyone finds a "good" ending please let me know and I will see if it is worth taking a look at.

32092712.review:
The description of this is what caught me during one of my “scroll through recs/sale items and download what looks interesting and is cheap” runs that I do during Steam and Humble sales.

I believe that gaming should not be anything complicated or diffcult, but a relaxing and pleasure experience. Therefore, I designed this ARPG battle system which requires no attack button to play. The simplicity brings a fluent and interesting gaming experience.

“Fluid” is definitely a good way to describe this game. It moves forward steadily, but still requires thought. The boss battles and puzzles increased in difficultly without ever becoming frustrating, which I thought was a pretty big accomplishment for such a small game. A completionist run is entirely doable without a guide thanks to the logical way in which things such as the locations of hidden chests are designed, which I appreciated. And true to the designer’s intentions, it is indeed a game anyone can play.

The game is also just the right length for what it has to offer. Another dungeon would have been boring, while one less would have been really, really short.

The game follows the titular Senia, who has entered the cursed Tower of Eternity to rescue her sister, Magaleta (I spent a large part of the game wondering if this was a botched translation of “Magdalena,” since it’s such an unnatural name linguistically). As the game progresses, Senia flashes back to the setup of their lives together and why Mag entered the tower in the first place.

The most glaring issue with the game is that the translation is very bad. The dev is Taiwanese, and it looks like he may have tried to translate it into English himself. This was a mistake, as while it’s still understandable, it doesn’t at any point resemble proper sentences. There were a few times I really had to guess at what he was trying to say. And worst of all, it annihilates any atmosphere the dialogue might have built and none of the characters have unique voices.

I also wasn’t a big fan of the true ending, since you basically end up right back where you started having accomplished nothing. It was too much of a sequel hook and not enough an actual conclusion. I’m shocked at the amount of games that have this problem, actually. To me it seems obvious that when writing even a basic story you should also include an ending. I suppose the issue is that inexperienced writers don’t know how to conserve interesting but unnecessary information — they see it as all-or-nothing, where the game either lays bare everything or hold all the cards close to its chest in lieu of an actual conclusion. This is one of the reasons I always tell people who want to write to read ravenously — seeing how sequels are properly set up goes a long way in not botching your own endings so badly.

I also have been led to understand the game uses a lot of basic rpgmaker assets, but that doesn’t really bother me and I’m always confused as to why people get so high and mighty about it. Surely there’s something impressive in and of itself about creating a unique-looking world from the same building blocks everyone else has. The character art, meanwhile, was clean if unremarkable.

“Clean if unremarkable” describes the whole experience pretty well, actually (except for the translation, which is entirely remarkable in how dirty it is). It offers a unique plot and relaxing gameplay, but not much else. I don’t regret playing it, but I won’t be watching for the sequel.

31589676.review:
Three words: slow and boring.


From the hour I've played of the game, all of the gameplay involves ramming your face into your opponent and killing them without them ever actually attacking, but instead just doing trivial counter damage when you hit them and then healing you when you kill them. Every enemy is the same, except the occasional archer, which, instead of having to dodge the arrows and go in when it's safe, the game immediately gives you a special ability to deal with it thoughtlessly by using MP which the enemies give back immediately. The only enemy in the first hour of gameplay which has any thought or skill required, heck, the only one who even requires you to DODGE AN ATTACK, was the first boss, and even he takes a day and a half to charge for the only attack he really does, which changes its properties randomly halfway through the fight with no indication, and then releases slimes for you to kill and get your health back, taking away what little challenge the boss had anyway.

The story feels stock and unimaginative, and the game crams it down your throat. The main character's primary, and only, motivation throughout what I've played is to find her sister, which is shown in two ways: (1) unskippable flashback cutscenes prompted by the most contrived plot device in a video game which fail to engage the watcher in any way and end up being little more than a roadblock in the way of what little gameplay this game has, and (2) moments in the "gameplay" in which the main character says that "it's dangerous to go ahead", but she "can't give up" because she has to "find her sister", which tries to make the player sympathize with the main character, but instead only makes the character's one-dimensionality even more obvious than it already is.

31285136.review: I was really surprised by this game. Normally, you would get something of this quality from something you paid around $10, $15 for. The grammar isn't the best, but that's easily something to overlook. One of the few things that I wasn't the happiest about was the battle system. You just walk up to the enemy and the you attack. Until you unlock magic attacks, there is no variation in attacks at ALL. Fans of games like EverQuest and Warframe, that are used to and enjoy the larger amount of variation may not appreciate this as much as they would appreciate previously stated games. But that's not what the developer was aiming for. This isn't a game based on combat. It's very story-rich and full of puzzles. It's not very long, maybe only 6 hours if you want to get all three endings (I was lazy, so I just watched them on Youtube), and the story really does give you the feels. After you get all three endings though, and possibly 100% it (getting all of the armor, weapons, etc.) there isn't really any replayability (is that a word?) Regardless of the battle system and the sometimes monotonous gameplay, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone willing to try it.

31194907.review:
Just finished the game, and I am impressed.
This game was free, and therefore, I did not expcted that much.
This game surely surpassed my expectation and went beyond.
It is a relatively short game, it took me about 3 good hours to finish (If you were to farm to maximum, then maybe +1 hour at most?). Despite being short, the charater development is enough and solid, while story progression is fast enough to give players feeling to rush through the ending. 

Also, this game has one of the unique style of game play. When encounter enemy, you dont go into that typical fight GUI or "screen" to engage each and every battle. Rather, you just simply hit them, and you either take damage back or dodge the counter attack. This simple and fast-pased battle system certainly helps players to enjoy the game, even if players are not very experienced compared to others. 

There are 3 different endings, and as story progresses, you kind of know what and how would you be able to accomplish all ending. Also, this game has a bit of puzzle aspect to it, which I enjoyed. (they are fairly easy too, including all the boss battles).

If you like RPG maker based game and want to enjoy a small, little story that is carefully packaged with emotions, for FREE, then this game is for you.

And to think this was done in RPGMaker... gotta practice my skills there even more. Heck, in the bonus room, we see parts of the creator's process in making this and you can feel the effort, with comments on how he fine-tuned this, and test-played, making changes as needed. Still, I would have liked more detailed equips, more skills, or even a skill tree...

STORY: Story is what you would expect for such a game- short. However, unlike most free rpgs I've seen, the story here is good! No, it's not on the level of the usual RPGs I play. The game's too short, and the cast too small for that. HOWEVER, this would be a very good backstory game for one such character in a larger cast in a bigger RPG. So no complaints here, really. I'd like to see Senia in a party with going back to the tower as her more personal motivation in joining the group.

MUSIC: It was pretty standard, I suppose. Not monotonous, but nothing super amazing either. Few tracks, but the short gameplay makes them stand out a bit without getting repetitive. One thing I would have liked is if the piano cutscene actually played a piano-only mix of the track...

ART: For most of the map sprites, it's the usual run from rpgmaker resources and other peoples stuff. Good enough, especially with the longer height sprites, but nothing much to be said. The conversational 'VN' sprites were somewhat lacking for me. They could have been done better. Plus, it would have been nice if the side characters (chest, slime, sheep, and Nia) would have conversation sprites while they talk. Same for the bosses. Speaking of which, the boss arts were pretty good, and the parallaxed maps were as well. The only thing that could have improved there was perhaps if the boss battles had the arts changing subtly, or moving like a GIF of sorts, but slow enough to keep the art quality.

OTHERS: Nice autosave system. It really takes out the frustration when you accidentally make a big mistake. Especially on the last parts- the game actually let's you save after the final boss for other things!

Overall, I'd give this a solid 9/10 considering the game length and the price. Worth every second I played :)

First off, it's free. So there's really no reason not to try it. That said, the game itself is fairly straight forward and easy. Controls are simple yet effective, but more importantly they are responsive, which makes a game like this playable.

 The story is quite fun and entertaining, including all three ending, that said the translation is rough in places and some of the dialogue could have done with a once over from a native speaker, that said it doesn't really take away from the enjoyment of the game at all, at least it didn't for me.

 I have about 4 hours into the game and honestly that was enough time to 100% it, beat all bosses on Hard find all pieces of gear so on and so forth. It's pretty simple and a fun little time waster, I'll be keeping an eye on the developer and supporting them with future games if they choose to release on steam.
